SUMMARY:
Instead of tucking into chocolate each day in December, thereâ€™s a way to enjoy advent calendars while helping others - and it wonâ€™t rot your teeth.
People around the world are making â€˜reverse advent calendarsâ€™, which involve filling a box with a useful item each day, then giving it to someone in need on Christmas Eve.
One CanNational charity Changing Lives is collecting calendars this year after its staff spotted the trend online.
While One Can are open on Christmas Eve to collect boxes, Changing Lives are asking for all donations by 15 December.
Changing Lives
TEXT:
Instead of tucking into chocolate each day in December, thereâ€™s a way to enjoy advent calendars while helping others - and it wonâ€™t rot your teeth. People around the world are making â€˜reverse advent calendarsâ€™, which involve filling a box with a useful item each day, then giving it to someone in need on Christmas Eve. The idea was the brainchild of Canadian Julie Van Rosendaal, who appealed for donations for her local food bank in place of calendars in November 2015. But the concept truly took off in the UK a month later, when South Shields resident Louise Scott pledged to donate a calendar to her local homeless shelter. Since then, numerous charities as well as a collection of bloggers have launched their own versions of the initiative. We spoke to two organisations collecting the calendars - One Can and Changing Lives - to find out everything you need to know about getting involved.

One Can

National charity Changing Lives is collecting calendars this year after its staff spotted the trend online. The charity runs projects dedicated to helping vulnerable people in the community, ranging from domestic violence survivors and sex workers to people recovering from addiction and those struggling to access mental health services. â€œWe thought this was a lovely, communal way for people to collect and donate to people in need,â€ communications manager Libby Marks tells HuffPost UK. â€œIt also gives people a sense of purpose during stressful Christmas trips to the shops, to know they have some small affordable items they can pick up to bring cheer to people in genuine need. â€œThe reverse advent calendars are small acts of kindness that add up to a massive difference for vulnerable people.â€ Meanwhile Buckinghamshire-based One Can is one of many food banks taking part in the initiative. This will be the charityâ€™s second year of collecting calendars after they proved to be a roaring success in 2016. â€œLast year, on Christmas Eve morning when we opened the food bank store, we had no idea how many people would come,â€ marketing and communications volunteer Heather Stanley tells HuffPost UK. â€œOver 250 families and individuals arrived with their calendars. Many happy tears were shed by us at the project.â€ Heather says the calendars can connect the community and help those struggling to feel less isolated. â€œIt is such a stressful time of year, with kids not in school so not getting their free meals, and with such innocent joy and expectation of a lush Christmas tea and presents galore, parents can often feel like they are letting their own kids down,â€ she says. â€œOur clients tell us that knowing people are thinking of those less fortunate than themselves at Christmas really encourages them.â€ According to Heather, giving an advent calendar can also help remind your family about the true meaning of Christmas. â€œFamilies brought their children along to the food bank on Christmas Eve and we got to talk about a different thing we can do at Christmas - sharing love,â€ she says. â€œSo we know it makes a huge difference to those receiving the parcels, but also to those giving.â€

One Can

How to make a reverse advent calendar: Heather says while food banks are â€œgrateful for every donationâ€, One Can has created a list of certain items theyâ€™re always short of that go into the emergency food parcels. These include:

:: Pasta sauce

:: Coffee/hot chocolate

:: Long-life milk

:: Toothbrushes and paste The charity will be posting a prompt on social media every day to inspire people, such as â€œDecember 1st: rice.â€ â€œAt Christmas, people like to pop in extras like mince pies and Christmas puds and thatâ€™s absolutely wonderful,â€ Heather adds. â€œIf people canâ€™t pop a food or household item in each day, a pound coin is also most welcome as it helps us run the project.â€ Meanwhile Changing Lives is primarily asking people to donate items that will be of use to the people who live in its accommodation projects. These include:

:: Unopened toiletries

:: Warm clothes for winter

:: Items to make rooms feel more homely

:: Books

:: Games

:: DVDs â€œPeople often arrive at our accommodation with very little,â€ Libby explains. â€œAs we work with a lot of women, we also ask for sanitary items because these can be a big expense for women experiencing hardship. We pop them into bedrooms and bathrooms to save women the embarrassment of asking for them.â€ Changing Lives also runs a crÃ¨che in Doncaster and several of its nationwide projects are aimed at supporting families with young children, so toys can be a great addition to your box. â€œWe ask people to not include food, alcohol or any toy weapons,â€ Libby says. While One Can are open on Christmas Eve to collect boxes, Changing Lives are asking for all donations by 15 December. Ask staff at your local charity what items they are in need of for more box inspiration.

Changing Lives
TITLE: Why You Should Create A Reverse Advent Calendar This Year (And How To Do It)

SUMMARY:
Now, less than twelve months later, it seems that scientists have forgotten about said incident, as NASA are asking people to name a new space object.
The Arctic explorer, worth a huge Â£200,000,000, was almost given the charming moniker after the naming process was left in the hands of the UK public.
On New Yearâ€™s Day 2019, the New Horizons spacecraft will be passing by a frozen world in the Kuiper Belt, located at the outer edge of our solar system.
The spacecraft is on the lookout for an object currently known as (486958) 2014 MU69.
So instead of continuing with this, frankly terrible name, NASA decided to ask the public for help in renaming the object, before the mission begins.
TEXT:
Now, less than twelve months later, it seems that scientists have forgotten about said incident, as NASA are asking people to name a new space object.

The Arctic explorer, worth a huge Â£200,000,000, was almost given the charming moniker after the naming process was left in the hands of the UK public.

Cast your mind back to simpler times - it was April 2016 and all Britain had to worry about was the fact we had just named a polar research vessel Boaty McBoatface.

On New Yearâ€™s Day 2019, the New Horizons spacecraft will be passing by a frozen world in the Kuiper Belt, located at the outer edge of our solar system.

The spacecraft is on the lookout for an object currently known as (486958) 2014 MU69. Really catchy.

So instead of continuing with this, frankly terrible name, NASA decided to ask the public for help in renaming the object, before the mission begins.

Alan Stern, New Horizons principal investigator from Southwest Research Institute in Boulder, Colorado. â€œWeâ€™re excited for the public to help us pick a nickname for our target that captures the excitement of the flyby and awe and inspiration of exploring this new and record-distant body in space.â€

The voting website currently includes names under consideration and site visitors can pick their favourite.

Some include AÃ±o Nuevo (meaning New Year in Spanish), Camalor (fictional city in the Kuiper Belt, Peanut, Almond, Cashew, Sagittarius (constellation behind MU69), Kibo (peak of Mt. Kilimanjaro) and MjÃ¶lnir (Thorâ€™s hammer).

You can also nominate a name you think should be added to the ballot.
TITLE: NASA Wants Us To Name A New Space Object, What Could Possibly Go Wrong

SUMMARY:
Try a Kris Kringle to cut down costs.
"Have a Kris Kringle, set a budget and then buy for one family member or a couple or what have you.
Often when you get to a certain age and Christmas comes around, you're thinking 'what else do I want?'
"Buy Christmas paper when it's on sale.
"You may also want to set up some kind of direct debit system that helps you save for Christmas next year.
TEXT:
Okay, so we don't mean to alarm anybody, but if you happen to get paid monthly, you have exactly two paydays left until Christmas rears it's expensive, tinselled head.

Or, to put it another way, there are eight Fridays between now and C-day. Eight.

So while it may be a little too late to start any proper Christmas financial planning, there are still some things you can do to ensure you don't end up spending your entire pay packet at Westfield on Christmas Eve (let's face it, probably on things you don't need and your relatives definitely don't want.)

Here are our top tips.

1. Make a list

No, we're not talking about times when you've been naughty or nice. We're talking about a list of all the things you need to buy. In other words -- no impulse purchases for you!

"Don't do last minute Christmas shopping. It will end up being all impulse buys. Figure out what you need to buy now -- plan it out and set a budget," CEO and founder of JBS Financial Strategists, Jenny Brown, told HuffPost Australia.

"No matter what it is, whether it's Christmas or saving for a holiday, it all comes back to setting a budget and setting a goal to make sure you are going to hit it."

2. Shop online

One of the great things about shopping online is it's so easy to shop around for the best price -- a practice Brown greatly encourages.

"If you know you are going to buy a certain article of clothing or present or whatever it's going to be, search around online," she said.

"It's amazing how much you can save. And if they deliver, have it delivered to your work so you save yourself the hassle of going to the post office to pick things up."

3. Consider a Kris Kringle

If you have a large family, it's well worth considering having a Kris Kringle, whereby participants draw a name out of the hat and just buy a present for that single person.

The great thing about a Kris Kringle (or Secret Santa gift exchange) is that not only does it keep costs down, but it means people are more likely to receive what they actually want rather than a whole bunch of smaller items that will end up in the bottom of a drawer.

Big family? Try a Kris Kringle to cut down costs.

"If you have a situation where there are 13 members in a family, it just becomes ridiculous," Brown said.

"Have a Kris Kringle, set a budget and then buy for one family member or a couple or what have you.

"Alternatively, just buy for the kids. Often when you get to a certain age and Christmas comes around, you're thinking 'what else do I want?' Eliminating the adults and just focusing on the kids can be a great way to bring down costs."

4. Don't use your credit card

This is probably going to be the toughest thing to do this Christmas, but you'll thank yourself next year when your bill isn't out of control.

"Be careful of the credit cards. Don't have the attitude of 'I'll deal with it in January', because then you have to pay it off, and how are you going to do that?" asks Brown.

"If you aren't good with that kind of discipline, use cash only. Get out the amount you're going to spend and shop according to your list. Really plan out what you are going to spend it on.

"Another trick is to freeze your credit card in water in a plastic container. If you want to use it, you'll have to defrost it, which reduces the chance of you impulse buying."

Home-made presents are thoughtful and kind to the bank balance.

5. Get crafty

Who's to say you have to spend a fortune on gifts? Why not embrace your inner hipster and plant some succulents or make some jam?

"That's actually one of the things we've done," Brown said. "I've been growing home made veggies and making things like homemade chutneys and jams.

"It's a lovely thoughtful gift as well as bringing costs right down, especially if you do things like recycle your jars."

6. Prepare for next year

If you want to put yourself in the best possible stead for Christmas 2018, it pays to start planning now.

"It's never too early to start," Brown said. "Buy Christmas paper when it's on sale. You can often get really good deals in January. That goes for cards too.

"You may also want to set up some kind of direct debit system that helps you save for Christmas next year.

"If you start planning ahead, it really does pay off in the long run."
TITLE: How To Avoid Spending Too Much This Christmas

Auf dem Bild ist erkennbar, dass dem Tier offenbar mindestens zwei Mal in seine Hinterbeine geschossen wurde, bevor es letztlich seinen Verletzungen erlag.

Um ein Zeichen gegen die Jagd des bedrohten Tieres zu setzen, startete die Umweltschutzorganisation TERA eine Petition gegen Golabchi.
TEXT:
Seit seinem 16. Lebensjahr macht Hossein "Soudy" Golabchi Jagd auf teils bedrohte Tiere

Das Bild, wie er stolz mit einem erlegten Schneeleoparden posiert, sorgt gerade fÃ¼r viel Aufregung

Bereits Ã¼ber 100.000 Menschen unterschrieben nun eine Petition um den Amerikaner hinter Gitter zu bringen

Unter Wilderern gilt er als eine Legende: Seit seinem 16. Lebensjahr macht der Amerikaner Hossein Golabchi, kurz als "Soudy" bekannt, Jagd auf teils stark bedrohte Tiere.

Ein Foto, das im Jahr 2008 entstanden sein soll und nun verÃ¶ffentlicht wurde, sorgt gerade fÃ¼r besonders viel EmpÃ¶rung unter TierschÃ¼tzern. Denn auf dem Bild ist der aus dem Iran stammende TrophÃ¤enjÃ¤ger zu sehen, wie er stolz mit einem toten Schneeleoparden Ã¼ber seinen Schultern posiert.

Auf dem Bild ist erkennbar, dass dem Tier offenbar mindestens zwei Mal in seine Hinterbeine geschossen wurde, bevor es letztlich seinen Verletzungen erlag. Das Tier soll er vor neun Jahren auf einer Jagd in Zentralasien erlegt haben. Die Jagd auf die bedrohte Wildkatzenart ist allerdings weltweit illegal. Trotzdem berichtete der SchÃ¼tze schon 2008 stolz Ã¼ber das Erlegen des Raubtieres in seinem Buch â€œObsessed!â€.

Illegaler Handel auf dem Schwarzmarkt

Leider ist der Schneeleopard unter sogenannten Wilddieben ein beliebtes Ziel, mit dem illegale HÃ¤ndler auf dem Schwarzmarkt viel Geld verdienen. Um ein Zeichen gegen die Jagd des bedrohten Tieres zu setzen, startete die Umweltschutzorganisation TERA eine Petition gegen Golabchi. Bis jetzt fand sie bereits UnterstÃ¼tzung von Ã¼ber 100.000 Menschen.

Die Tierschutzaktivistin Amanda W. schreib dazu:

â€œWir mÃ¼ssen bei diesem langjÃ¤hrigen und auÃŸerordentlich aktiven TrophÃ¤enjÃ¤ger seltener Raubkatzen ein Exempel statuieren, sonst werden diese wundervollen Tiere fÃ¼r immer verschwinden. Ich habe diese Petition am Internationalen Tag des Schneeleoparden 2017 gestartet. Lasst uns alle zusammen arbeiten, damit dieser Mann bis zum Schneeleoparden-Tag 2018 zur Rechenschaft gezogen wird.â€

Ãœber 400 wilde Tiere

Wie viele Tiere Soudy in seiner Karriere insgesamt erlegt hat, ist unklar.

Allerdings stellt er laut "Superslam", einem Wettbewerb unter WildjÃ¤gern, die ihn 2003 mit einem Award ehrten, allein in seinem eigenen Museum 400 wilde Tiere 225 verschiedener Spezien aus.

TERA sieht den TrophÃ¤enjÃ¤ger als ein Symbol der Wilddieberei, die mit ihren Errungenschaften Geld im Darknet verdienen. Daher ist ihr Ziel ihn als Beispiel vieler ins GefÃ¤ngnis zu bringen. Obwohl das Erlegen des Wildtieres bereits vor einigen Jahren stattgefunden hat, wÃ¼rden FÃ¤lle der Wilddieberei nicht verjÃ¤hren.

Obwohl sich Hossein Golabchi auf Anfrage vieler Medien zu dem Fall bisher nicht geÃ¤uÃŸert hat, gab TERA nun bekannt, dass er laut eigenen Angaben die Ãœberreste des Leopards erst nach Deutschland gebracht und daraufhin nach Mexiko verschifft habe. Eine genaue detaillierte Stellungnahme werde momentan erwartet.

Vor dem Aussterben bedroht

Seit 1972 gilt der Schneeleopard als eine vor dem Aussterben bedrohte Tierart. Laut dem Naturschutzbund NABU gibt es in ganz Asien nur noch rund 4.000 frei lebende Schneeleoparden. Allein in Kirgistan sank die Zahl der Wildkatzen in 30 Jahren von 1.400 auf nur noch rund 300 Exemplare.

Wenn ihr auch etwas gegen die illegale Jagd auf die Tiere unternehmen wollt, kÃ¶nnt ihr hier die Petition von PERA gegen Hossein Golabchi unterschreiben oder euch hier bei Tierschutzorganisationen wie NABU oder WWF Ã¼ber weitere MÃ¶glichkeiten der UnterstÃ¼tzung informieren.

While Tim Hortons has a giant menu featuring new drinks and doughnuts every couple of months, a true Timmies lover knows there are a bunch of tasty menu items that aren't blatantly advertised.
While they may not be actual products themselves â€” like some restaurants with "secret dishes" â€” Tim Hortons is known for simple everyday hacks.

TEXT:
Once you've dealt with PATIENCE at the drive-thru, you engage the Fruit of the Spirit is Love......A large double double.

There's no real secret behind Tim Hortons' secret menu.

If you've been modifying or adding substitutes to your food and drink orders for as long as you can remember, you're already part of the movement. While Tim Hortons has a giant menu featuring new drinks and doughnuts every couple of months, a true Timmies lover knows there are a bunch of tasty menu items that aren't blatantly advertised.

While they may not be actual products themselves â€” like some restaurants with "secret dishes" â€” Tim Hortons is known for simple everyday hacks. It could be something as simple as warming up already beloved dishes, or adding veggies where they don't already exist, to make your daily routine a little different.

And since these menu items aren't necessarily healthier either, we do suggest checking out the site's nutrition board to figure out exactly what you're eating (if you're worried, that is).

We asked readers to share their favourite off-menu Tim Hortons items and how to customize everyday favourites. Which ones did we miss? Let us know in the comments below:

Der Physiker Stephen Hawking warnt die Menschheit vor den Gefahren neuer Technologien

Er denkt, dass kÃ¼nstliche Intelligenz zu unserem Ende fÃ¼hren kÃ¶nnte

Welche Gefahren laut Hawking konkret von kÃ¼nstlicher Intelligenz ausgehen kÃ¶nnen, erfahrt ihr im Video oben

Es ist ein Thema, das die Menschheit seit Jahren beschÃ¤ftigt: In den letzten Jahren behandelten Hollywood-Filme wie Steven Spielbergs â€œA.I.- KÃ¼nstliche Intelligenzâ€ oder â€œI, Robotâ€ mit Will Smith immer wieder die mÃ¶glichen Gefahren von kÃ¼nstlicher Intelligenz. Was bisher nur als Science Fiction galt, wird nun immer mehr zur RealitÃ¤t.

Erst in der vergangenen Woche wurde in Saudi Arabien weltweit zum ersten Mal einem Roboter, der Androidin Sophia, die StaatsangehÃ¶rigkeit zugesprochen. Das berichtete unter anderem das Online-Magazin "Live Science".

Auf einer Technologie-Konferenz in Lissabon wandte sich der berÃ¼hmte Physiker Stephen Hawking nun an die Menschheit, um vor dieser Entwicklung zu warnen.

Das berichtet der amerikanische Nachrichtensender CNBC. Er warnt, dass der Fortschritt kÃ¼nstlicher Intelligenz das Potential habe, die Menschheit zu zerstÃ¶ren.

"Diese neue Form des Lebens wird den Menschen Ã¼bertreffen"

In seiner Rede erklÃ¤rt er: â€œComputer kÃ¶nnen theoretisch menschliche Intelligenz nachahmen und diese auch Ã¼bertreffen. Wenn wir erfolgreich kÃ¼nstliche Intelligenz erzeugen kÃ¶nnen, wÃ¤re das das wichtigste Ereignis unserer Geschichte. Oder das schlimmste. Das wissen wir einfach noch nicht.â€

Hawking Ã¤uÃŸerte sich in letzter Zeit immer wieder zu den Entwicklungen in der Technologie. GegenÃ¼ber dem Magazin â€œWIREDâ€ sagte er erst kÃ¼rzlich: â€œIch befÃ¼rchte, dass kÃ¼nstliche Intelligenz die Menschheit gÃ¤nzlich ersetzen wird. Wenn Menschen Computerviren designen kÃ¶nnen, dann kÃ¶nnen sie auch kÃ¼nstliche Intelligenz kreieren, die sich selbststÃ¤ndig verbessern und replizieren kann. Diese neue Form des Lebens wird den Menschen Ã¼bertreffen.â€

"Wenn ihr nett zu mir seid, bin ich nett zu euch"

Mit seinen Ã„ngsten ist Hawking nicht alleine. WÃ¤hrend Facebook-GrÃ¼nder Mark Zuckerberg laut CNBC â€œoptimistisch den groÃŸartigen MÃ¶glichkeiten durch kÃ¼nstliche Intelligenz entgegensiehtâ€, Ã¤uÃŸerte sich BillionÃ¤r Elon Musk sehr kritisch gegenÃ¼ber den neuesten Entwicklungen. Er ist der Ansicht, dass der Mensch mit den Maschinen eins werden mÃ¼sse, um auf Dauer nicht irrelevant zu werden.

In einer Pressekonferenz antwortete die Androidin Sophia in Saudi Arabien auf die Gefahren ihrer â€œSpeziesâ€: â€œSie haben zu viel von Elon Musk gelesen und zu viele Hollywood-Filme angesehen. Wenn ihr nett zu mir seid, bin ich nett zu euch.â€

Aufnahmen von ihr findet ihr auch im Video oben.

Welche Gefahren oder MÃ¶glichkeiten auf uns zukommen werden, kann allerdings wohl letztlich nur die Zeit zeigen.

TITLE: Stephen Hawking warnt vor einer neuer Lebensform: "Sie kÃ¶nnte unsere Zivilisation zerstÃ¶ren"

Der Film bescherte ihm und Kumpel Matt Damon (47) nicht nur den groÃŸen Durchbruch, sondern auch einen Oscar.

"Alle zukÃ¼nftigen Tantiemen, die ich von Miramax oder einem Weinstein-Film bekomme, werden entweder an den F.I. [Film Independent] oder an RAINN [Rape, Abuse & Incest National Network] gehen. SUMMARY:
A huge void has been discovered in the Great Pyramid of Giza by scientists using an imaging method based on cosmic rays.
The researchers said it constitutes the first major inner structure found in the Great Pyramid since the 19th century.
The Great Pyramid, looming alongside other large pyramids on the outskirts of Giza, is the last of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World still standing.
Scan Pyramids Mission 3D scans with lasers and drones were also used as part of the investigationIt was constructed during the reign of the Pharaoh Khufu, or Cheops.
travelshooter via Getty Images The Great Pyramid soars to a height of 479 feetâ€œWe are not doing this mission in order to find hidden cavities,â€ Helal said.
TEXT:
A huge void has been discovered in the Great Pyramid of Giza by scientists using an imaging method based on cosmic rays. Experts announced the find on Thursday but have admitted they donâ€™t know what the cavity inside the pyramid, built as a monumental tomb around 2560BC, is for. To see inside the pyramid, the scientists used an imaging technique called muon tomography that tracks particles that bombard Earth at close to the speed of light and penetrate deeply into solid objects.

Scan Pyramids Mission Experts have admitted they don't know what the giant void in the Great Pyramid of Giza is for

They said the newly discovered internal structure was at least 100 feet long, and located above a hallway measuring about 155 feet long called the Grand Gallery, one of a series of passageways and chambers inside the immense pyramid. The researchers said it constitutes the first major inner structure found in the Great Pyramid since the 19th century.

â€œWhat we are sure about is that this big void is there, that it is impressive, that it was not expected by, as far as I know, any kind of theory,â€ said Mehdi Tayoubi, president and co-founder of the HIP Institute in France, one of the leaders of the study published in the journal Nature.

Scan Pyramids Mission The void was discovered using cosmic particle detectors

â€œWe open the question to Egyptologists and archaeologists: what could it be?â€ added Hany Helal of Cairo University. The Great Pyramid, looming alongside other large pyramids on the outskirts of Giza, is the last of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World still standing. It soars to a height of 479 feet, the tallest structure built by humankind until the Eiffel Tower in Paris in 1889, and boasts a base measuring 754 feet.

Scan Pyramids Mission 3D scans with lasers and drones were also used as part of the investigation

It was constructed during the reign of the Pharaoh Khufu, or Cheops. Zahi Hawass, a previous Egyptian antiquities minister, believes the pyramid still contains the tomb of Khufu and that it is unplundered.

DEA / G. DAGLI ORTI via Getty Images An ivory statuette of Khufu

Ahead of the discovery, he told The Times: â€œI really believe that [Khufuâ€™s] chamber is not discovered yet and all the three chambers were just to deceive the thieves, and the treasures of Khufu [are] still hidden inside the Great Pyramid.â€ The findings come from a project called Scan Pyramids that relies on non-invasive scanning methods to probe the internal structure of the pyramids of ancient Egyptâ€™s glorious Old Kingdom period and understand how they were built.

travelshooter via Getty Images The Great Pyramid soars to a height of 479 feet

â€œWe are not doing this mission in order to find hidden cavities,â€ Helal said. Muon particles originate from interactions between cosmic rays from space and atoms of Earthâ€™s upper atmosphere. The particles can penetrate hundreds of yards into stone before being absorbed. Placing detectors inside a pyramid can discern cavities within a solid structure.

Scan Pyramids Mission Infrared thermography readings of the structure were also taken
TITLE: Mysterious Void Found In Egypt's Great Pyramid Of Giza

SUMMARY:

"Someone is apparently trying to sell naked photos of me to my fans," Furler tweeted on Tuesday afternoon, "Save your money, here it is for free".
Someone is apparently trying to sell naked photos of me to my fans.
pic.twitter.com/aeQlnTwLuy â€” sia (@Sia) November 7, 2017Furler's screenshot of the cheeky image also included a message from the seller attempting to exploit her for their financial gain.

TEXT:
We've all gotten used to Sia Furler hiding her face during performances and appearances, but now the 'This Is Acting' singer has acted boldly after someone tried to exploit her.

"Someone is apparently trying to sell naked photos of me to my fans," Furler tweeted on Tuesday afternoon, "Save your money, here it is for free".

Someone is apparently trying to sell naked photos of me to my fans. Save your money, here it is for free. Everyday is Christmas! pic.twitter.com/aeQlnTwLuy â€” sia (@Sia) November 7, 2017

Furler's screenshot of the cheeky image also included a message from the seller attempting to exploit her for their financial gain. "If you make the purchase," the message reads, "it will be unblurred and you will receive and [sic] additional 14 images".

After Furler posted the image her fans were quick to embrace the move of undercutting the gross invasion of her privacy.

Iï¸ thought Iï¸ couldn't love you any more than when Iï¸ saw you singing to a baby at a coffee shop in Echo Park but here we are November 7, 2017

Furler is currently working on a festive album 'Everyday Is Christmas' which is set to release on November 17.
TITLE: Someone Was Trying To Sell Nude Photos Of Sia So She Tweeted One Herself

SUMMARY:
Parents have set up an online petition calling for a local county council to apologise for an â€œaggressive, condescending, insultingâ€ campaign that aims to reduce unauthorised absences during the school term.
East Sussex County Council launched the â€˜Get A Gripâ€™ campaign this week to educate families and carers about primary school students taking time off for sickness and holidays.
â€œYou are accusing parents of failing their children without any concern for context or appropriateness,â€ said Ella Lewis from Seaford, who started the petition.
The mother explained that a â€œblind attackâ€ from the council on families whose children miss school is not helping matters.
East Sussex County Council
TEXT:
Parents have set up an online petition calling for a local county council to apologise for an â€œaggressive, condescending, insultingâ€ campaign that aims to reduce unauthorised absences during the school term. East Sussex County Council launched the â€˜Get A Gripâ€™ campaign this week to educate families and carers about primary school students taking time off for sickness and holidays. But the adverts, which appeared on bus stops, social media, and local radio, failed to resonate with over 8,000 parents who have now signed a letter claiming the ads are unfit for purpose and â€œwill probably prove to be counterproductiveâ€. â€œYou are accusing parents of failing their children without any concern for context or appropriateness,â€ said Ella Lewis from Seaford, who started the petition. â€œThis is disgusting and offensive and it is even worse when applied to families who are struggling with serious illnesses, traumas and ongoing disabilities and conditions.â€

East Sussex County Council

East Sussex County Council distributed the letters to children who had missed at least three days in the first half of the autumn term, which ran from 5 September to 20 October. Bob Standley, the councilâ€™s head of education and inclusion, said: â€œThereâ€™s a perception among some parents that 95% attendance is enough, but this is simply not the case.â€ But Lewis says that the slogans used in the campaign - â€œget a grip, most parents doâ€, â€œgood reasons for missing school - there are none,â€ and â€œdonâ€™t be a mugâ€ - are dividing and alienating parents. The mother explained that a â€œblind attackâ€ from the council on families whose children miss school is not helping matters. â€œEven when you are taking a firm stance on the subject, you need to convince and win the commitment of parents, not bully us into submission,â€ she said.

East Sussex County Council
TITLE: Council Faces Backlash From Parents Over 'Get A Grip' Campaign Targeting Absentee Children

AperÃ§ue dans les sÃ©ries "Greek" ou "Californication", la jeune comÃ©dienne annonce dans son message avoir vÃ©cu "un cauchemar" il y a trois ans. Un cauchemar dont Ed Westwick serait responsable.

"Le mois qui vient de s'Ã©couler a Ã©tÃ© extrÃªmement difficile. Comme tant de femmes, j'ai aussi une histoire d'agression sexuelle. La multiplication des histoires a Ã©tÃ© un dÃ©clencheur mais aussi Ã©puisante Ã©motionnellement. Je remuer tout Ã§a dans ma tÃªte, ne sachant pas si je devrais parler. Si je pouvais parler. Et si je le faisais, serai-je entendu?

J'ai Ã©tÃ© agressÃ© sexuellement il y a trois ans. C'Ã©tait une pÃ©riode sombre de ma vie. Ma mÃ¨re Ã©tait en train de mourir d'un cancer et je n'avais ni le soutien ni le temps nÃ©cessaire pour gÃ©rer les sÃ©quelles du viol. J'ai enterrÃ© ma douleur et ma culpabilitÃ© pour faire de la place Ã  ce qui se passait. Ma mÃ¨re est morte 3 mois plus tard.

Encore maintenant, je me laisse prendre par des sentiments de culpabilitÃ©. Cette inquiÃ©tude infondÃ©e qui suggÃ¨re que d'une certaine faÃ§on je suis Ã  blÃ¢mer. Creuser et revivre cette nuit afin de partager avec prÃ©cision les Ã©vÃ©nements, m'a donnÃ© le sentiment d'une agression en continue. Mon estomac est nouÃ©, Ã  cause de mon anxiÃ©tÃ© Ã  rendre Ã§a public. MÃªme me rÃ©concilier complÃ¨tement avec moi-mÃªme a Ã©tÃ© un processus dur.

Ã€ l'Ã©poque je frÃ©quentais briÃ¨vement un producteur qui Ã©tait ami avec l'acteur Ed Westwick. C'est ce producteur qui m'a amenÃ© chez Ed oÃ¹ je l'ai rencontrÃ© pour la premiÃ¨re fois. Je lui ai dit d'arrÃªter, mais il Ã©tait fort. Je l'ai repoussÃ© aussi fort que possible, mais il a saisi mon visage dans ses mains, m'a secouÃ©, et m'a dit qu'il voulait me baiser. J'Ã©tais paralysÃ©e, terrifiÃ©e. Je ne pouvais pas parler, je ne pouvais plus bouger. Il m'a maintenue et m'a violÃ©e.

Il m'a dit que je ne pouvais rien dire parce qu'Ed avait de l'influence et que si je parlais je pourrais oublier ma carriÃ¨re d'actrice. J'y ai cru. Je ne voulais pas Ãªtre "cette fille".

Je me rends compte dÃ©sormais de la faÃ§on dont ces hommes de pouvoir s'attaquent aux femmes, et comment cette tactique est si frÃ©quemment utilisÃ©e dans notre industrie, et sÃ»rement, dans beaucoup d'autres.

Je suis Ã©cÅ“urÃ©e de voir des hommes comme Ed respectÃ©s publiquement. InterviewÃ©s par de prestigieuses institutions telles que l'Oxford Union Society de l'UniversitÃ© d'Oxford, oÃ¹ il a Ã©tÃ© honorÃ© comme l'une des "personnes qui faÃ§onnent notre monde". Comment cela peut-il arriver? Les hommes comme Ed utilisent la cÃ©lÃ©britÃ© et le pouvoir pour violer et intimider, et continuent Ã  parcourir le monde en distribuant les accolades.

J'espÃ¨re que mon histoire aidera les autres Ã  savoir qu'elles ne sont pas seules, qu'elles ne sont pas responsables et que ce n'est pas de leur faute; tout comme les autres femmes et hommes qui se sont confiÃ©s m'ont aidÃ© Ã  rÃ©aliser la mÃªme chose. J'espÃ¨re que mes histoires et les histoires des autres aideront Ã  maÃ®triser ces environnements toxiques et Ã  supprimer les dÃ©sÃ©quilibres de pouvoir qui ont crÃ©Ã© ces monstres".

SUMMARY:

Ya nadie llora por mÃ­ (Alfaguara) es su Ãºltima novela, y en ella confluyen los diferentes Sergio RamÃ­rez (Masatepe, Nicaragua, 1942).
Sobre todo, el insatisfecho y comprometido con la realidad al indagar en las cloacas polÃ­ticas de Nicaragua y el tejido que se pudre en la sociedad.
Un gran parÃ©ntesis literario, aunque siempre trabajÃ³ por la cultura y la literatura, en el que formÃ³ parte de la ReconstrucciÃ³n Nacional.
Me parece que la gran lucha es con el lenguaje, el lenguaje que es tan movedizo.
TEXT:
Por Winston Manrique Sabogal

Cincuenta y cuatro aÃ±os despuÃ©s de todo tipo de batallas culturales, polÃ­ticas y literarias, la serenidad sigue en Ã©l. En su cara, en sus gestos, en sus andares, en su trato, en su voz. Hasta la risa de Sergio RamÃ­rez es tranquila. Un hombre apasionado con la literatura, pero cuya vocaciÃ³n parece ser la de divulgador, agitador y gestor cultural y literario interesado en dar a conocer a escritores y en recordarle o descubrirle a la gente el placer de la lectura.

Ya nadie llora por mÃ­ (Alfaguara) es su Ãºltima novela, y en ella confluyen los diferentes Sergio RamÃ­rez (Masatepe, Nicaragua, 1942). Sobre todo, el insatisfecho y comprometido con la realidad al indagar en las cloacas polÃ­ticas de Nicaragua y el tejido que se pudre en la sociedad. Y para eso nadie mejor que volver al inspector Dolores Morales que en otros tiempos fue guerrillero del Frente Sandinista de LiberaciÃ³n Nacional (FSLN) de Nicaragua. Una especie de alter ego de la esperanza y del propio RamÃ­rez.

Un camino culebrero el de este escritor: abogado, periodista, narrador, ensayista, biÃ³grafo, editor, gestor cultural que entrÃ³ en la polÃ­tica al liderar con intelectuales, empresarios y dirigentes civiles el llamado Grupo de los Doce que apoyÃ³ la revoluciÃ³n sandinista para derrocar la dictadura en su paÃ­s de Anastasio Somoza en 1979. Un gran parÃ©ntesis literario, aunque siempre trabajÃ³ por la cultura y la literatura, en el que formÃ³ parte de la ReconstrucciÃ³n Nacional. En 1984 fue elegido vicepresidente de un gobierno presidido por Daniel Ortega hasta 1990 y luego, hasta 1995, estuvo en la Asamblea Nacional de Nicaragua. Un aÃ±o despuÃ©s se presentÃ³ a la presidencia sin ser elegido.

Pero la literatura lo ganÃ³. Dos aÃ±os despuÃ©s, en 1998, obtuvo el primer Premio Alfaguara de Novela con Margarita, estÃ¡ linda la mar. Y en 1999 contÃ³ su experiencia polÃ­tica y revolucionaria con mano maestra en AdiÃ³s muchachos.

RamÃ­rez reemprendiÃ³ el camino definitivo iniciado en 1963, cuando, con 21 aÃ±os, publicÃ³ su primer libro: Cuentos. Desde entonces una treintena de ficciones y casi veinte ensayos que lo han llevado por toda clase de temas en una literatura fresca y Ã¡gil en la que han cambiado algunas cosas y otras las mantiene. En un hotel de Madrid, el escritor echa la vista atrÃ¡s.

A travÃ©s de cuento aprendÃ­ a ver, a escribir, y a escribir lo que me rodeaba. Ese fue un desarrollo temprano de espÃ­ritu de observaciÃ³n, de registrar cada detalle de situaciones que parecerÃ­an que merecÃ­an ser relatadas. Fortalecer este vÃ­nculo entre lo que uno ve y lo que el otro piensa que no ve... Creo que eso ha permanecido igual en mÃ­ desde los primeros cuentos. Lo que he cambiado es el sentido de la improvisaciÃ³n por el de la meditaciÃ³n.

SolÃ­a escribir de manera apresurada, me preocupaba muy poco en corregir. Por esa Ã©poca editÃ¡bamos la revista Ventana. Me parecÃ­a que la literatura era algo urgente. HacÃ­a un par de correcciones y ya... Ahora me ocurre lo contrario, corrijo muchÃ­simo. Me parece que la gran lucha es con el lenguaje, el lenguaje que es tan movedizo. Buscar que la imagen se corresponda con las palabras para mÃ­ es el arte de la escritura.
TITLE: Sergio RamÃ­rez: â€œVivimos en una sociedad acalambrada bajo el precio del temorâ€

TEXT:
La lista delle star americane del grande o piccolo schermo che hanno subito - o operato - abusi e violenze sessuali si allunga sempre di piÃ¹ col passare dei giorni e ora ad essere accusato di stupro Ã¨ il protagonista della serie tv Gossip Girl, Ed Westwick. Con un lungo post su Facebook, infatti, l'attrice Kristina Cohen ha raccontato di essere stata violentata dal collega che presta il volto a Chuck Bass.

"Lo scorso mese Ã¨ stato davvero difficile per me" inizia a raccontare la donna. "Anche io, come molte altre donne, sono stata vittima di un abuso sessuale in passato, tre anni fa. [...] Era un periodo molto buio della mia vita. Mia madre stava morendo di cancro e io non ho avuto il supporto e il tempo per elaborare il lutto del mio stupro. Ho sepolto dolore e senso di colpa".

Nonostante anche oggi l'attrice si senta colpevole della violenza subita, lo scandalo legato ad Harvey Weinstein e i conseguenti racconti di molte donne - famose e non - l'hanno spinta a non tacere piÃ¹: "Uscivo da poco con un produttore amico di Ed Westwick. Lui mi ha portato a casa di Ed ed Ã¨ stato lÃ¬ che l'ho incontrato per la prima volta. Quando Ed ha suggerito che avremmo dovuto tutti avere un rapporto sessuale, volevo andare via, ma il produttore non gradiva fare uno sgarbo ad Ed. Lui ha insistito affinchÃ© rimanessimo per cena. Ho risposto che ero stanca e che avrei preferito andarmene, era una situazione imbarazzante".

Le insistenze dell'attore e del produttore hanno fatto poi desistere Kristina dal lasciare la casa. Westwick le suggerÃ¬ di fare un pisolino nella camera degli ospiti e cosÃ¬ fece la donna, all'epoca 25enne. "Sono stata svegliata bruscamente da Ed, era sopra di me, le sue dita erano all'interno del mio corpo. Gli ho chiesto di smettere, ho lottato contro di lui ma era troppo forte. Mi ha stretto la faccia tra le sue mani, mi ha scosso e detto che voleva scop***i. Ero paralizzata, terrorizzata. Non riuscivo a parlare e a muovermi. Mi ha trattenuta e mi ha stuprata".

La Cohen decise di raccontare tutto al suo fidanzato il giorno dopo, ma non ricevette il conforto che si aspettava: "Il produttore mi incolpÃ² dell'accaduto, mi ha detto che ero stata una partecipante attiva. Mi ha avvertito di non raccontare nulla, perchÃ© Ed avrebbe potuto farmi pedinare da qualcuno e distruggere me e la mia carriera".

A distanza di tempo, perÃ², Kristina ha voluto di uscire dal silenzio: "Sono stufa di vedere come Ed sia rispettato, intervistato e invitato su palcoscenici prestigiosi come quello della Oxford University. [...] Gli uomini come Ed usano il potere e la fama per stuprare e intimidire le donne". Westwick non ha ancora commentato l'accusa della collega.
TITLE: "Ero paralizzata. Mi ha trattenuta e mi ha stuprata". Ed Westwick di "Gossip Girl" accusato di stupro dall'attrice Kristina Cohen

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTThe Morning Wrap is HuffPost India's selection of interesting news and opinion from the day's newspapers.
Essential HuffPostNavin Singh's goof-up of Vande Mataram's lyrics exposes BJP's hypocrisy on patriotism, writes Sandip Roy, urging the ruling party to practice what it preaches.
In a first, the Supreme Court Wednesday directed the Centre to constitute special courts to exclusively try criminal cases involving politicians.
The call for it should emanate from all self respecting citizens who place a premium on the rule of law, writes HS Puri and HS Khalsa in the Hindustan Times.
The definition of harassment needs to be constantly updated, and the process for justice made more robust, argues Veena Venugopal in The Hindu.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

The Morning Wrap is HuffPost India's selection of interesting news and opinion from the day's newspapers. Subscribe here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.

Essential HuffPost

Navin Singh's goof-up of Vande Mataram's lyrics exposes BJP's hypocrisy on patriotism, writes Sandip Roy, urging the ruling party to practice what it preaches.

India jumped into 100th place on the World Bank's ranking of countries by Ease of Doing Business for the first time in its report for 2018, up about 30 places, driven by reforms in access to credit, power supplies and protection of minority investors.

Hollywood star Dustin Hoffman has been accused of sexually harassing a 17-year-old intern on the set of his 1985 TV adaptation Death of a Salesman.

Main News

A massive explosion ripped a boiler at the state-run power giant NTPC's Unchahar plant in Uttar Pradesh's Rae Bareli district today, killing at least 20 people and injuring nearly 100, officials said.

At least two people were killed and one injured in a shooting inside a Walmart store in suburban Denver on Wednesday, police said.

In a first, the Supreme Court Wednesday directed the Centre to constitute special courts to exclusively try criminal cases involving politicians.

Off The Front Page

In a first, an Indian canine breed is being trained for induction into the Army, which has been using foreign breeds like German Shepherds, Labradors and Great Swiss Mountain dogs till now.

A week after a man allegedly pushed off four of his daughters from a running train, resulting in the death of one of the girls in Uttar Pradesh's Sitapur district, government railway police traced the culprit's house in Bihar's Bettiah town. The accused is still absconding.

A day after naming Prem Kumar Dhumal as the BJP's chief ministerial candidate in Himachal Pradesh, party chief Amit Shah hit out at incumbent CM Virbhadra Singh and Congress vice president Rahul Gandhi saying they were deeply enmeshed in corruption.

Opinion

In The Indian Express, Pratap Bhanu Mehta writes about the strategies employed by the Chinese Communist Party to bury the revolutionary spirit of 1917.

The Sikh community has largely moved on from the massacres of 1984 but justice still eludes them. The call for it should emanate from all self respecting citizens who place a premium on the rule of law, writes HS Puri and HS Khalsa in the Hindustan Times.

The definition of harassment needs to be constantly updated, and the process for justice made more robust, argues Veena Venugopal in The Hindu.

Also on HuffPost
TITLE: The Morning Wrap: BJP's Patriotism Fail; SC Wants Special Courts To Try Politicians

Wir haben die heutigen Aussagen des GrÃ¼nen-Chefs in diese Richtung als Signal der Einigungsbereitschaft aufgenommen, wie Christian Lindner ja auch deutlich gemacht hat. Klare, erreichbare Ziele und Technologieoffenheit zu ihrer Erreichung statt auf Verbote zu setzen, das muss die Devise sein. Und so ist es auch mit der Kohlekraft.



Warum?



Wir haben jetzt schon Probleme mit der Versorgungssicherheit. Bei manchen Unternehmen flackert das Stromnetz und gefÃ¤hrdet damit die Produktion, weil der Strommix aus den Erneuerbaren in StoÃŸzeiten nicht ausreicht. Wenn wir die Kohle jetzt parallel zur Kernenergie aus dem Stromnetz rausnehmen, mÃ¼ssen wir mit flÃ¤chendeckenden Blackouts rechnen. Das kann niemand wollen.



Was ist mit Erdgas? Das ist effizienter und nicht ganz so schmutzig wie Kohle.



Fakt ist doch: Bislang haben uns die GrÃ¼nen nicht vorrechnen kÃ¶nnen, wie sie einen Kohleausstieg ausgleichen wollen. Da bliebe uns nur Ã¼brig, Kohle- und Kernenergie aus Frankreich und Polen zuzukaufen. Ob die GrÃ¼nen so wirklich das Klima retten, bezweifle ich.



Reden wir Ã¼ber den Umgang zwischen den Jamaika-Parteien. FDP-Chef Lindner hat den GrÃ¼nen etwa vorgeworfen, ein â€œKonjunkturprogramm fÃ¼r die AfDâ€ zu betreiben. CSU-General Scheuer nennt die GrÃ¼nen â€œschizophrenâ€. Woher kommt die schlechte Laune?



Wir schauen schlicht auf die RealitÃ¤ten. Beispiel FlÃ¼chtlingspolitik, worauf sich das Zitat von Christian Lindner ja bezog. NatÃ¼rlich ist ein Familiennachzug, wie ihn die GrÃ¼nen wollen, in gewissen Bereichen sinnvoll - etwa, wenn derjenige seine Familie hier in Deutschland ernÃ¤hren kann, weil er einen Job und eine Wohnung hat.

Aber das funktioniert nur, wenn wir diejenigen abschieben, die kein Bleiberecht haben. Sonst werden uns die BÃ¼rger zurecht auf die Barrikaden gehen. Denn wir kÃ¶nnen nicht jeden aufnehmen.



Wie wollen Sie die GrÃ¼nen davon Ã¼berzeugen?



Es gibt auch bei den GrÃ¼nen Politiker wie Herrn Palmer, die davon bereits Ã¼berzeugt sind. Sie wissen, dass es vor Ort Schwierigkeiten gibt, einen unbegrenzten Zuzug von FlÃ¼chtlingen zu schultern. Es fehlen Wohnungen, KlassenrÃ¤ume, LehrkrÃ¤fte und Kita-PlÃ¤tze.



Herr Palmer aber spricht nicht fÃ¼r seine Partei. Wie wollen Sie etwa Parteichef Ã–zdemir Ã¼berzeugen?



Ich setze darauf, dass auch Cem Ã–zdemir irgendwann fÃ¼r logische Argumente zugÃ¤nglich wird und in seinem Wahlkreis merkt, dass auch dort nicht alle FlÃ¼chtlinge aufgenommen werden kÃ¶nnen.



Schauen wir auf CSU-Chef Horst Seehofer. Es wirkt so, als liefe gegen ihn ein innerparteilicher Putsch. Glauben Sie, dass er noch lange am Verhandlungstisch von Jamaika sitzen wird?



Das muss die CSU entscheiden.



Lohnt es sich, Kompromisse mit jemandem zu machen, der womÃ¶glich schon bald nicht mehr fÃ¼r seine Partei spricht?



Am Ende des Tages machen wir Kompromisse mit der CSU, nicht mit Horst Seehofer.

Beobachter sehen die Jamaika-Verhandlungen durch die Personaldiskussion in der CSU grundsÃ¤tzlich in Gefahr. Teilen Sie diese Sorge?



Unsere Verhandlungen kÃ¶nnten schneller voranschreiten, wenn die CSU so geschlossen wÃ¤re wie die FDP. Aber Streit gibt es auch bei den GrÃ¼nen, die sich untereinander nicht immer einig sind.

TEXT:
MALTRAITANCE ANIMALE - Une enquÃªte filmÃ©e en camÃ©ra cachÃ©e rÃ©vÃ¨le les conditions de vie -et surtout de mort- des souris dans un grand laboratoire parisien. RÃ©alisÃ©e par l'association Animal Testing, elle a Ã©tÃ© relayÃ©e par LibÃ©ration ce lundi 6 novembre. Face camÃ©ra, le visage et la voix brouillÃ©s pour garantir son anonymat, une technicienne de laboratoire tÃ©moigne de la duretÃ© de ces conditions de travail face Ã  la souffrance infligÃ©e aux animaux, images Ã  l'appui. La vidÃ©o peut Ãªtre visionnÃ©e sur Youtube, attention, certaines images peuvent heurter la sensibilitÃ©.

Pour elle, c'Ã©tait la demande de trop, qui l'a poussÃ©e Ã  contacter l'association. "On ne peut pas prÃ©lever du sang sur un Ãªtre vivant jusqu'Ã  temps qu'il n'y ait plus de sang, comme si c'Ã©tait un flacon, et qu'il meure de ce qu'on lui fait subir."

D'aprÃ¨s cette technicienne, interrogÃ©e par LibÃ©ration, le laboratoire parisien accueille simultanÃ©ment plusieurs milliers de souris, modifiÃ©es gÃ©nÃ©tiquement dans la plupart des cas et rendues malades. Certaines ont des tumeurs tellement grosses qu'un chercheur s'amuse: "c'est comme si elles se baladaient avec un sac Ã  dos".

"Ce n'est pas Ã©vident les dislocations vertÃ©brales"

En thÃ©orie, les animaliers de laboratoires doivent "apporter un bien-Ãªtre aux animaux de laboratoire et assurer la prise en charge technique des expÃ©rimentations", rÃ©sume la fiche Onisep de la profession. La lanceuse d'alerte, elle, s'occupe de changer leurs litiÃ¨res, de les sevrer, de prÃ©lever leur sang, organes, tumeurs, leur injecter des produits ou des cellules cancÃ©reuses. Et de les tuer.

Une technique courante, indique-t-elle dans la vidÃ©o, est la dislocation verticale, que l'on voit rÃ©alisÃ©e par une autre salariÃ©e. Elle consiste Ã  tirer brusquement sur la queue et la tÃªte de l'animal, et qui ne marche pas toujours du premier coup. "Ã‡a j'en ai fait, je dirais, des centaines de fois", tÃ©moigne la lanceuse d'alerte.

D'autres souris sont intoxiquÃ©es au CO2, d'abord endormies dans un caisson puis mises Ã  mort. Une autre animaliÃ¨re commente: "Quand j'en ai le temps, je fais comme Ã§a, parce que ce n'est pas Ã©vident les dislocations vertÃ©brales". Dans les images filmÃ©es, une souris continue de se dÃ©battre dans ce caisson alors que toutes les autres sont mortes.

Les protocoles scientifiques sont en thÃ©orie censÃ©s prendre en compte des "points limites" de douleur. Dans la rÃ©alitÃ©, ils ne sont pas toujours respectÃ©s, comme en atteste cette enquÃªte. Certaines souris perdent leurs yeux dans ces expÃ©riences, ou deviennent aveugles. D'autres meurent de leurs souffrances. Certains protocoles prÃ©voient mÃªme de ne pas les anesthÃ©sier, pour ne pas interfÃ©rer avec les rÃ©sultats des expÃ©riences.

La directive europÃ©enne qui encadre ces expÃ©riences Ã©rige normalement trois rÃ¨gles centrales, baptisÃ©es les trois R: la rÃ©duction du nombre d'animaux, le raffinement dans leur prise en charge, et, Ã  terme, leur remplacement.

"Le modÃ¨le des animaux n'est pas forcÃ©ment le bon"

Dans les faits, tÃ©moigne la lanceuse d'alerte, les scientifiques poursuivent les tests sur animaux par habitude. Quand elle les interroge Ã  ce sujet, ils lui rÃ©pondent ainsi: "parce que quand j'ai fait des Ã©tudes, on a Ã©tudiÃ© sur des souris, quand on Ã©change avec des confrÃ¨res ou Ã  travers les pays, comme tout le monde a dÃ©jÃ  travaillÃ© avec des souris, on continue Ã  le faire".

Pour les animaliers qui travaillent avec ces animaux, cette situation est d'autant plus dure que le veto dont ils disposent en thÃ©orie sur certaines expÃ©riences est trÃ¨s souvent outrepassÃ©. "Ã‡a nous dÃ©truit", insiste la technicienne. "Il n'y a plus de goÃ»t Ã  la vie." Au bas de la hiÃ©rarchie, leur parole n'est guÃ¨re Ã©coutÃ©e, ajoute-t-elle.

Elle-mÃªme Ã©tait dans un premier temps favorable Ã  ces tests, qu'elle jugeait comme un moindre mal. Mais en intÃ©grant le comitÃ© d'Ã©thique du laboratoire, elle prend conscience que les souris sont traitÃ©es "comme des objets".

1,9 millions d'animaux ont Ã©tÃ© utilisÃ©s en 2015 dans la recherche, d'aprÃ¨s une enquÃªte du ministÃ¨re de l'enseignement supÃ©rieur, de la recherche, et de l'innovation. Parmi tous ces cobayes, plus d'un million de souris ont Ã©tÃ© employÃ©es.

TEXT:
Der zweijÃ¤hrige Raphael leidet an einer aggressiven Art von LeukÃ¤mie

Deshalb ist die Familie jetzt extra nach Seattle geflogen - und hofft auf eure Hilfe

Margit und Andreas Fischer haben nicht eine Sekunde gezÃ¶gert, als sie sich in der Haunerschen Kinderklinik in MÃ¼nchen entscheiden mussten, ob ihr Sohn leben oder sterben soll. Raphael ist zwei Jahre alt und leidet an einer besonders aggressiven Form des Blutkrebses, der sogenannten akuten lymphatischen LeukÃ¤mie (ALL).

Weil die Behandlungen in Deutschland nicht mehr anschlugen und es dadurch nur noch wenig Hoffnungen fÃ¼r den Jungen gab, empfahlen die Ã„rzte eine letzte Alternative: eine neuartige dreimonatige Immunbehandlung an der WestkÃ¼ste in Amerika.

FÃ¼r die Eltern gab es keine Diskussionen. Ihr Sohn soll leben. Seit gut einer Woche ist die Familie jetzt an der WestkÃ¼ste der USA, um sich auf die Therapie vorzubereiten.

Raphael leidet an akuter lymphatischer LeukÃ¤mie. Eine schmerzvolle und belastende Zeit begann fÃ¼r die Familie, die noch bis heute anhÃ¤lt.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Meine Tochter hatte Krebs - jetzt kÃ¤mpft sie fÃ¼r andere Kinder

Der kleine Raphael musste einen fÃ¼nfmonatigen Chemoblock, zwei AntikÃ¶rperbehandlungen sowie zwei Knochenmarktransplantationen Ã¼ber sich ergehen lassen.

Erst kÃ¼rzlich wurde die Immuntherapie in den USA zugelassen. Laut Fachmedien zeigten klinische Studien, dass sie bei mehr als 80 Prozent der Patienten angeschlagen habe. FÃ¼r Raphael ist diese Therapie die letzte Chance, den Blutkrebs endgÃ¼ltig zu besiegen.

SUMMARY:
If eating nut butter by the spoonful is your guilty pleasure youâ€™re in for a treat of epic proportions.
Popular brand Whole Earth is launching its very first pop-up bar in London, where nut butters will be transformed into glorious fondue.
Nut butter lovers can take part in a two hour feasting extravaganza, trying both sweet and savoury fondues from Original Peanut Butter to Chocolate Peanut Butter.
On departure, diners will leave with all the info they need to recreate the fondues themselves at home.

SUMMARY:
Hurricane Maria, one of the strongest ever to hit Puerto Rico, caused unprecedented damage to the islandâ€™s already fragile power grid.
The lack of electricity is significantly slowing the entire US relief effort on Puerto Rico.
In a darkened Puerto Rico, where cellphones donâ€™t work and clean water doesnâ€™t flow, thereâ€™s never been more of a need for electricity.
Battered by Hurricane Maria, Puerto Rico has never needed electricity more but had less of itThe reasons have to do with geography and money.
On my last night in Puerto Rico, I have dinner with a businessman whoâ€™s lived in San Juan for decades.
TEXT:
ADJUNTAS, Puerto Rico â€” In the final frantic days before Hurricane Maria devastated this small town in the mountains of central Puerto Rico, Rosana Aviles Marin did everything she could to help her elderly parents prepare for what was coming.

She brought in food and water, and used plywood to reinforce the walls and roof of their modest two-story cement house. It didnâ€™t matter. The winds of up to 155 miles per hour that roared across the island buckled the houseâ€™s walls and tore holes in the ceiling, letting in water that destroyed furniture, framed photos of Marin and her siblings, and brightly colored ceramic statues of Jesus.

That wasnâ€™t all it destroyed. The storm also downed power lines throughout the area, and Marin and her parents have been entirely without electricity for weeks. Much of their food went bad, they have no cellphone service, and local markets and restaurants remain closed. Her parents use a small diesel generator to power lights and, for a few hours per day, a small refrigerator. The rest of the time, she tells me during a recent trip to the area, â€œmy parents live in darkness.â€

They arenâ€™t the only ones. Hurricane Maria, one of the strongest ever to hit Puerto Rico, caused unprecedented damage to the islandâ€™s already fragile power grid. Four weeks after making landfall, roughly 79 percent of the island still doesnâ€™t have electricity.

Local and federal officials say it will be months before the power is fully restored, and they acknowledge that in some places it could take far longer because their crews have yet to even reach the hardest-hit areas. The head of Puerto Ricoâ€™s debt-ridden power utility says repairs will cost $5 billion; some officials privately tell me the figure will be far higher.

With the national grid down for the foreseeable future, generators are in such high demand that their prices have skyrocketed, putting them out of reach of many average Puerto Ricans. There are regular reports of generators being stolen from outside homes and businesses.

Walking through the walled neighborhood of Old San Juan, the islandâ€™s main tourist attraction, I see police officers installing floodlights in a central square and then flipping on a shiny new generator. One of the officers tells me heâ€™ll be there all night to keep an eye on the equipment. â€œIt would otherwise be gone by morning,â€ he says, shrugging.

Electricity is something you donâ€™t notice until itâ€™s gone. On the mainland, where power outages are rare and brief, Americans are used to simply flipping a switch and watching the light come on, plugging in an air conditioner and feeling the cold air, and trusting that your refrigerator will keep fresh food and milk from going bad.

When the power goes out, that sense of comfort quickly disappears. The parts of daily life that were once taken for granted are suddenly gone, with no clear sense of when theyâ€™ll be back. To not have power â€” to be literally and figuratively in the dark â€” is to leave the modern world and retreat into an older and more precarious one. In the aftermath of Hurricane Maria, thatâ€™s Puerto Ricoâ€™s new normal.

The lack of electricity doesnâ€™t simply mean months of hardship for the hundreds of thousands of Puerto Rican who will be without air conditioners, fans, televisions, and refrigerators for the foreseeable future. Itâ€™s also significantly slowing the entire US relief effort, and preventing other vital parts of the islandâ€™s battered infrastructure from coming back online.

Internet and cellphone service canâ€™t be fully restored without a steady flow of electricity to individual cell towers. The pumps, filtration systems, and other equipment used to treat sewage and provide clean drinking water also canâ€™t function without power. Right now, those plants arenâ€™t receiving much of it.

The lack of electricity is significantly slowing the entire US relief effort on Puerto Rico. Cellphone networks and water systems wonâ€™t come back online without it.

â€œPeople need to understand this is not something that can be turned on tomorrow,â€ JosÃ© SÃ¡nchez, who is leading the Army Corps of Engineersâ€™ program to restore the grid, tells me in an interview in San Juan. â€œThis something thatâ€™s going to take months to fix. Weâ€™re dealing with a very tender system, a very sensitive system, and it will require a lot of work to get it back up.â€

SÃ¡nchez, a soft-spoken man who uses the precise language of a trained engineer, says the Corps could eventually bring at least 500 of its employees to the island, alongside 1,000 private contractors. He was born in Puerto Rico, and says the effort to bring power back is deeply personal for him. The island canâ€™t recover, much less prosper, without it.

â€œI think of electricity like water, as a basic need and a basic requirement to have a semi-normal life,â€ he tells me. â€œElectricity is the linchpin of everything.â€

That means the lack of electricity is a literal life-and-death issue â€” and one that may wind up killing more Puerto Ricans than the storm itself. The islandâ€™s government says 48 people died because of the hurricane, but my colleagues Eliza Barclay and Alexia FernÃ¡ndez Campbell estimate that the real death toll from the storm is probably well into the hundreds.

That number could spike even higher if the blackouts continue because the island needs electricity to operate its water and sewage systems; if the grid remains offline, huge numbers of Puerto Ricans will be at real risk of dying from heatstroke, dehydration, or exposure to contaminated water.

In a darkened Puerto Rico, where cellphones donâ€™t work and clean water doesnâ€™t flow, thereâ€™s never been more of a need for electricity. Itâ€™s also never been in such short supply â€” or so difficult and expensive to bring back.

Puerto Ricoâ€™s power system was a mess before Maria. Now itâ€™s barely clinging to life.

President Trumpâ€™s slow and halting response to the Puerto Rico crisis has been widely criticized, with a new poll showing that public approval for Trumpâ€™s handling of recent hurricanes has plummeted by 20 points in less than a month. (Trump himself, it should be noted, rates his response as a â€œ10.â€)

Trump has also been hammered for a series of recent tweets that appeared to blame Puerto Rico itself for the islandâ€™s current woes. One said â€œTexas & Florida are doing great but Puerto Rico, which was already suffering from broken infrastructure & massive debt, is in deep trouble.â€ Another said â€œitâ€™s [sic] old electrical grid, which was in terrible shape, was devastated.â€

But hereâ€™s the thing: The substance of what Trump said about the electrical grid was largely correct. The island's grid is antiquated and hasnâ€™t received any major upgrades in years. Power outages were a regular part of daily life on the island even before the storm (a 2016 report found they were four to five times more common on the island than in the mainland US). Maria has made those shortfalls exponentially worse, but it didnâ€™t cause them.

Battered by Hurricane Maria, Puerto Rico has never needed electricity more but had less of it

The reasons have to do with geography and money. Puerto Ricoâ€™s biggest power generators are on the south of the island, but most of its inhabitants live on the north side, primarily in San Juan. There are four high-capacity transmission lines that carry power from the south to the north, and they pass through the center part of the island, the region Marin calls home. The problem is that central Puerto Rico is mountainous, full of huge swaths of thick forest, and mainly reachable only by driving on terrifyingly narrow dirt roads.

That makes it hard to reach those four vital lines even in the best of circumstances. In post-Maria Puerto Rico itâ€™s even harder, because the center of the island was the region hardest hit by the hurricane. Since the government is trying to get power to San Juan first, that means those in the regions devastated most by the hurricane will be waiting the longest for power to be restored. SÃ¡nchez, the engineer, says workers would need to be flown in by helicopter to clear debris before repairs could even begin. As of now, three of those four lines are inoperable.

The second major problem is a financial one. PREPA, the islandâ€™s widely despised electric utility, hasnâ€™t done any major upgrades to the grid in decades. The median age of the islandâ€™s power plants is 44 years, more than double the normal industry standard of 18 years, according to a report from FiveThirtyEight. The plants are so old that itâ€™s hard to find replacement parts when individual pieces of equipment break down.

Itâ€™s also difficult to find workers who know how to keep that aging equipment up and running. Voxâ€™s FernÃ¡ndez Campbell reported last month that PREPA has lost thousands of workers in recent years, including 600 â€” fully a tenth of its workforce â€” this past April alone.

Ricardo Ramos, who runs PREPA, says that bringing the grid back to its pre-Maria state could cost up to $5 billion. The problem is that the utility itself is more than $9 billion in debt and filed for bankruptcy this past summer.

That means money for repairs, let alone upgrades, can only really come from two places.

One is Congress, which passed legislation in mid-October authorizing $36.5 billion in hurricane and wildfire relief. The package included $4.9 billion in loans for Puerto Ricoâ€™s cash-strapped government, which filed for a form of bankruptcy in May. Lawmakers from Florida and Texas have indicated that theyâ€™re going to ask for tens of billions of dollars more, though itâ€™s not clear if Congress will sign off on the additional money, or how much of it would make its way to Puerto Rico.

The other way to raise funds is through higher rates on the utilityâ€™s customers, but the Puerto Rico Energy Commission, which oversees PREPA, might not sign off on them. There are also legitimate concerns that Puerto Ricans, who already pay some of the highest electricity rates in the US and are now facing widespread unemployment because of the storm, wonâ€™t be able to afford to pay them.

JosÃ© RomÃ¡n Morales, the head of the commission, tells me that the island needs to find a way to get the old system back to its pre-Maria state â€” which would bring power back to desperate citizens sooner â€” while looking for ways to modernize and upgrade it.

â€œThatâ€™s the main topic of conversation at the moment,â€ he says. â€œThereâ€™s an emergency that needs to be addressed, and we need to get power to the hospitals and other essential institutions for life on this island. But stopping there isnâ€™t enough. One way or another, we have to make the grid more resilient and energy-efficient.â€

Renewable energy is one appealing option, since the island has an abundance of sun and wind. Tesla founder Elon Musk says he can build a new and more efficient grid that would use solar power to generate electricity.

Puerto Rican Gov. Ricardo RossellÃ³ says he wants to talk to Musk in more detail, but itâ€™s not clear who would pay for Muskâ€™s proposed system given that both the electrical utility and the island itself have declared bankruptcy. (RossellÃ³ has also promised to bring power back to 95 percent of the island by Christmas, a deadline US officials here dismiss as unrealistic.)

As Voxâ€™s Umair Irfan notes, building a grid centered on renewable energy would almost certainly be more expensive than reconstituting the flawed system that was there before the storm. That means â€œthe default solution â€” rebuilding the islandâ€™s electrical grid the way it was â€” may end up becoming the likeliest scenario,â€ he explains.

For now, the military and civilian officials working to pull Puerto Rico back from the brink are focused on bringing powerful generators to the island. Lt. Gen. Jeffrey Buchanan, the three-star Army general leading US military relief efforts in Puerto Rico, says civilian personnel are surveying hospitals, water plants, and sewage treatment facilities to find out which facilities have generators that are already working, which have ones in of need repair, and which donâ€™t have any at all.

â€œIf they don't have a generator, do they need one, and can we bring one in?â€ he tells me. â€œAnd when we talk generators, I'm not talking your little Honda one. Iâ€™m talking about massive generators, like the size of a semi-truck.â€

FEMA has already installed 100 generators at individual hospitals, sewage treatment plants, and water pumping facilities. It plans to bring in up to 400 more, according to officials on the ground here.

Generators are a short-term fix, however; a permanent solution will take far longer.

That is, in part, because of the technological hurdles to generating renewable energy on the island â€” especially in the aftermath of the hurricane.

A high-tech wind farm is ready to start producing power. Hereâ€™s why it canâ€™t.

On a sweltering day in mid-October, Ruben Rivera drives his cluttered pickup truck down the mottled mud roads that run through his companyâ€™s wind farm in Santa Isabel, in the far south of Puerto Rico. As we make our way across the property, Rivera points to row after row of towering white wind turbines.

Built by the German industrial giant Siemens at a cost of more than $2 million apiece and capable of adjusting themselves to keep pace with shifting wind patterns, the 44 wind turbines at Santa Isabel are some of the most advanced on earth. They also, to Riveraâ€™s surprise, made it through the hurricane without a single scratch or dent.

Rivera, who runs the facility on behalf of its owner, California-based Pattern Energy, lives about 90 minutes away from Santa Isabel. He rode out the storm at home with his wife and children, and waited until the worst of the weather had passed before setting off for the wind farm, afraid of what heâ€™d find.

â€œI was counting the number of turbines on the drive down because I kept thinking that we must have lost some,â€ he tells me. â€œBut then I saw that they were all still standing, and that they looked intact. Weâ€™ve checked the turbines and blades, and I havenâ€™t seen any damage. Theyâ€™re ready to goâ€

Rivera stops his pickup truck next to one of the turbines, clambers up a metallic staircase, takes the padlock off a small door, and steps inside the towering structure.

The interior is spotless, with a ladder extending up through a hole in the ceiling that can be used to climb to the very top of the 24-story tower. The power is generated by three long, tapered white blades, and then brought down to the base of the structure by a thick bundle of cables that connect to a large metallic box a few feet from the door. Rivera points to the floor, where other cables carry the power out of the turbine and then onto the grid. There isnâ€™t a speck of dirt, despite the fact that one of the strongest hurricanes in US history roared though the area less than a month ago.

There also isnâ€™t any noise. The turbines are in perfect working order and could be a vital source of energy for the power-starved island. Except that they canâ€™t actually be turned on without a small amount of electricity from the grid â€” which, of course, isnâ€™t currently capable of providing it.

When the grid eventually comes back online, the wind farm will be able to provide power to about 35,000 homes. Until then, the blades arenâ€™t turning.

Rivera, in the meantime, spends his time checking, and rechecking, each turbine so they can be turned on as soon as the power starts flowing again. Heâ€™s on a clock. Siemens, the manufacturer, says the turbines canâ€™t sit idle for more than six weeks without potentially damaging the equipment. The hurricane slammed into Puerto Rico almost a month ago, so each day brings that deadline closer.

â€œItâ€™s frustrating coming to the site and trying to provide energy to the grid but not being able to because weâ€™re still waiting for the power to come back,â€ Rivera tells me. â€œThe equipment is ready to go. Weâ€™re ready to go. But I donâ€™t know when weâ€™ll be able to start back up again.â€

Puerto Ricoâ€™s medical system is being reshaped by the hurricane

The lack of electricity is reshaping Puerto Rican life in ways big and small. Itâ€™s also forcing many here to improvise solutions to problems they never thought theyâ€™d face.

The community health center in LoÃ­za, a small town about 20 minutes outside of San Juan, is a low-slung gray building set just off the main road. When I visit it on a warm, cloudy day in October, the facility is eerily quiet and empty. The TVs are turned off, the information booth is empty, and steel shutters cover the windows of the pharmacy.

The medical center is still in operation, however, though at a severely reduced capacity than it had been before the storm. Dr. MarÃ­a RodrÃ­guez, who runs the facility, has worked there in various capacities for 24 years. She says she expected the storm to be bad but was still taken aback by the hurricaneâ€™s destructive power.

She leads me back to her cluttered office, which is filled with overflowing boxes of medical supplies, diapers, baby formula, Purell hand sanitizer, and small packets of childrenâ€™s multivitamins shaped like gummy bears. A pile of shrink-wrapped sleeping bags sits on the floor near her desk. â€œMy office has become a distribution center,â€ she says with a half-smile.

In the weeks since the storm, RodrÃ­guez and her staff have worked with LoÃ­zaâ€™s municipal government to ensure a steady supply of the diesel needed to power the centerâ€™s generators. Most parts of the center â€” from OB-GYN services to its primary care clinic â€” are functioning, though for fewer hours and without air conditioning.

The medical center, though, is rapidly changing its normal ways of doing business in order to adapt to the new reality on the ground. RodrÃ­guez tells me that many local residents have lost their homes and are living in large communal shelters. They may not know the medical center is open; even if they do, they often have no way of getting here.

In response, RodrÃ­guez is sending doctors and nurses to the shelters, which are already seeing periodic outbreaks of infectious diseases such as conjunctivitis and parasite-borne skin diseases like scabies. Thatâ€™s a new approach for the medical center, but RodrÃ­guez feels like sheâ€™d be letting down her community if she didnâ€™t experiment with alternative methods of delivering care. â€œThis is our new normal,â€ she says.

The lack of power is changing life on Puerto Rico. It will take a long time for it to change back.

On the outskirts of LoÃ­za, several concrete pylons that once held power lines lie shattered on the side of the road, a loose tangle of metallic rebar sticking up from the wreckage. Work crews are out installing new wooden poles, but there are dozens â€” in both directions â€” that still need to be replaced. The repair work will take weeks, and LoÃ­za is only one small town on an island teeming with larger ones.

Back in San Juan, the only part of the city with steady and reliable electricity is the area surrounding the cityâ€™s gleaming convention center, which is now the headquarters for the military and civilian relief effort. The power is also on at the Sheraton hotel across the street, as well as in its bustling casino, which has one of the few ATMs on the island that is still distributing cash.

The light starts to fade as I drive away from the convention center and make my way through blackened streets lined with shuttered restaurants and stores. A small number of houses, office buildings, and apartment buildings have their own generators, but itâ€™s possible to drive for blocks without seeing any lights.

On my last night in Puerto Rico, I have dinner with a businessman whoâ€™s lived in San Juan for decades. Heâ€™s survived other hurricanes, but heâ€™s not sure the island will bounce back from this one. At 11:15, he excuses himself and says he needs to start heading home to make sure heâ€™s off the roads before the cityâ€™s midnight curfew goes into effect. He has a long drive ahead of him, and the trip back always takes longer in the dark.
TITLE: Darkness: life in Puerto Rico without electricity
