TEXT:
Since leaving the villa this summer, itâ€™s fair to say that â€˜Love Islandâ€™ finalist Camilla Thurlow hasnâ€™t take the traditional reality TV star route. In lieu of endorsing weight-loss teas and hitting every D-list red carpet going - choices that Camilla is careful not to judge or look down on, we should add - she headed straight to Greece with former co-star Jamie Jewitt, to lend her hand to helping refugees. She later joined the cast of HuffPost UK original series â€˜New Activistsâ€™, documenting her recent trip to the site of the former jungle camp in Calais, alongside Help Refugees.

HuffPost UK Camilla Thurlow

HuffPost UK recently caught up with the former bomb disposal worker about how â€˜New Activistsâ€™ felt the like the right fit for her, why the refugee crisis means so much and what itâ€™s like breaking the reality TV star mould... What made you want to get involved with â€˜New Activistsâ€™? Having seen the other â€˜New Activistsâ€™ and what theyâ€™d been working on, you could see that it was really opening peopleâ€™s eyes to a whole different side of activism. Like, it was humanising the people involved. In some instances thereâ€™s been a bit of a stigma attached to activism, and people would consider activists to be only a certain type of person. But actually this documentary series has really given an insight into the fact itâ€™s just about normal people who feel very strongly, and thereâ€™s so many different sides to that person. Itâ€™s all about big ideas but with very real people. People know you best from â€˜Love Islandâ€™, and after being on a show like that, you get a lot of offers. How did you decide what to do next? I think itâ€™s all about authenticity, really, on that side of things, and I know what I think Iâ€™m good at, and it tends to be stuff that I feel passionately about. If Iâ€™m going to do something, I like to do it justice. For me it was just important to find the right thing, and also to try and make sure that I was using any platform that I might have to raise awareness for certain issues that I donâ€™t think necessarily always get seen. Itâ€™s that thing, interestingly, of different horses for different courses. I have so much admiration for the other things that people have done, and this seemed like the right opportunity for me. On â€˜Love Islandâ€™, we saw how much you wanted to do more activism. Did you ever worry that being on a show like that would limit your options? Of course there were concerns in my mind in terms of going back to the work that I did before, and I think obviously itâ€™s always worth having those concerns and having a healthy level of worry about what youâ€™re going to do next, because it makes you stay on the right track. So I guess I was worried to an extent, but I think it was the same for all of us who were in it from the beginning. When we came out we just didnâ€™t realise how successful the series had been, and how successful it had been across so many different demographics. It was really a very diverse audience andâ€¦ I think there was definitely something in the timing, this summer was quite an interesting time on many different levels with domestic and foreign politics, and somehow in that. â€˜Love Islandâ€™ became this really engaging escapism. So Iâ€™ll say that I did have concerns, but in the same way I would have had concerns about many different things and how that could affect my work.

ITV Camilla and her 'Love Island' co-stars this summer

Do you hope that your involvement in â€˜Love Islandâ€™ and â€˜New Activistsâ€™ can possibly inspire a new breed of celebrities who start on reality shows? I think the thing is, itâ€™s really interesting because I feel like there are comparisons being drawn that arenâ€™t as clear as it might appear. I donâ€™t feel as different [to other reality stars] as sometimes people perceive it. Iâ€™m struggling to explain myself, but I think itâ€™s very easy to label someone as a â€œtypical reality TV starâ€ but that person will have many other sides to them. The only thing that I sort of hope will happen is that... if I can raise any awareness of the issues that are important to me, that will make me very happy. What is it about the refugee crisis in particular that spoke to you? I think part of it comes from my previous work, pre- â€˜Love Islandâ€™. When you go to an area where thereâ€™s been a conflict and you can see people have been forced to leave their homes behind, and then youâ€™re involved in trying to make the area safe so they can come backâ€¦ you start to think about what it must mean for that person. To have literally got to a point where they had no choice but to leave, but also what growing up against that backdrop of violence can do to a person. Also, because I was on the EOD [explosive ordnance disposal] side, I wasnâ€™t seeing much of the people who had been forced to leave, so it was really important to me to build up that whole picture of what the results of conflict are. So, I initially took the trip to Greece with Jamie [Jewitt, her boyfriend and fellow â€˜Love Islandâ€™ star] and that was certainly an eye-opener, from that point on we just realised how much we could be doing to help people, and i just wanted to be a part of that. So how did your trip to Calais come about? I spoke to Josie [Naughton], whoâ€™s the co-founder of Help Refugees about supporting them. Itâ€™s been a year since the demolition of the Jungle camp in Calais, and since then, people have been homeless, living rough - not that they had homes before, but there was some form of camp, some form of protection, and they are now completely exposed. And that includes a number of unaccompanied children who are sleeping rough, completely unprotected, no one to stop anything happening to them. The more I discussed it with her, the more I realised first of all that I needed to see it for myself, and secondly that I wanted to be a part of trying to highlight the fact that there is a legal route for these children to come here, there is a safe way and that needs to happen urgently. Especially now itâ€™s coming up to winter. In the year since the jungle camp closed, how has the situation in Calais changed? I think itâ€™s worse, for the people who are there at the moment. It would be wrong for me to draw any sort of straight of judgement, because I didnâ€™t see it before. But we spoke to a gentleman called Stu in the distribution centre, and he had been in the jungle camp, and he said for him the conditions are worse. Now, theyâ€™re not even allowed tents to sleep in, so now they get a sleeping bag and a blanket at best, and even those are often taken away by the police, so the conditions are really really bad. In terms of keeping track of people, in making sure that they havenâ€™t been hurt or harmed, that they havenâ€™t attempted to cross and then not made it back and theyâ€™re stranded somewhere on their own, itâ€™s just so much harder when thereâ€™s no formalised systems.

A post shared by Camilla Thurlow (@camillathurlow) on Oct 26, 2017 at 4:36am PDT
TITLE: 'Love Island' And 'New Activists' Star Camilla Thurlow Talks Swapping 'Love Island' For Activism And Volunteering In Calais

SUMMARY:
Truly autonomous vehicles are, itâ€™s fair to say, still some way off from being sold and used on the roads.
Yet a new study has claimed that self-driving cars only have to be moderately better than human drivers before they could start saving lives.
This is compared to waiting until cars are at least 75% or 95% better than their human counterparts.
The study came up with the figures by estimating future road fatalities over hundreds of different futures while taking into account the numerous safety requirements for autonomous vehicles to be introduced.
â€œIf we wait until these vehicles are nearly perfect, our research suggests the cost will be many thousands of needless vehicle crash deaths caused by human mistakes.
TEXT:
Truly autonomous vehicles are, itâ€™s fair to say, still some way off from being sold and used on the roads. While itâ€™s true that weâ€™re getting ever closer to overcoming the technological hurdles in our way, regulations are such that allowing fully-autonomous vehicles onto the roads is difficult. Yet a new study has claimed that self-driving cars only have to be moderately better than human drivers before they could start saving lives.

Bloomberg via Getty Images

The report, published by non-profit organisation the RAND Corporation, has found that if we allowed the use of self-driving cars that were just 10% better than current American drivers it could prevent thousands of deaths over the next 15 years. This is compared to waiting until cars are at least 75% or 95% better than their human counterparts. The study came up with the figures by estimating future road fatalities over hundreds of different futures while taking into account the numerous safety requirements for autonomous vehicles to be introduced. While carmakers are testing the water with semi-autonomous systems like Teslaâ€™s Autopilot, very few are capable of achieving self-driving outside of a pre-determined environment e.g. Motorways.

Bloomberg via Getty Images

Despite this, the study argues that even rolling them out en masse in their current form could still prove to be a safer decision than not. â€œOur work suggests that it is sensible to allow autonomous vehicles on Americaâ€™s roads when they are judged to be just moderately safer than having a person behind the wheel,â€ said Nidhi Kalra, co-author of the study and director of RANDâ€™s San Francisco office. â€œIf we wait until these vehicles are nearly perfect, our research suggests the cost will be many thousands of needless vehicle crash deaths caused by human mistakes. Itâ€™s the very definition of perfect being the enemy of good.â€ Of course itâ€™s nowhere near as simple as just putting driverless cars on the road, thereâ€™s public opinion to consider as well.
TITLE: Introducing Self-Driving Cars Sooner Could Save Hundreds Of Thousands Of Lives, Claims Study

SUMMARY:
Odessa, Texas, was the 23rd stop on our Listen to America road trip.
Itâ€™s something different.â€â€• Leslie Robles, 18, shift managerâ€œOdessa is a great place really.
It was really different from my hometown, but adjusting to it wasnâ€™t really a problem for me.â€â€• Lauren Marenco, 18, studentâ€œI really like it here.
I think what makes Odessa special is the people here ...
I fell in love with Odessa when I was a kid because Iâ€™ve always felt comfortable.â€â€• Jacyree Webbs, 19, sales/student
TEXT:
Odessa, Texas, was the 23rd stop on our Listen to America road trip. We spoke to residents about why theyâ€™re there. Hereâ€™s what they had to say:

â€œI decided to come here so I wouldnâ€™t be that far away from home ... Thereâ€™s a big difference from El Paso to Odessa, but I really like it. Itâ€™s something different.â€

â€• Leslie Robles, 18, shift manager

â€œOdessa is a great place really. Everyone has their opinions about it. It has its own beauty. It has its own culture. It has its own attraction.â€

â€• Scott Windham, 37, sales

â€œPeople are so divided on things and so polarized and thatâ€™s what I try to teach is civil discourse. To get along, listen to the other side, and realize that everybody doesnâ€™t believe in the same thing that you do. Whether itâ€™s guns on campus, gun control, religion, politics ...â€

â€• Myra Salcedo, 67, university senior lecturer

â€œI like it. It was really different from my hometown, but adjusting to it wasnâ€™t really a problem for me.â€

â€• Lauren Marenco, 18, student

â€œI really like it here. I think what makes Odessa special is the people here ... I would say Odessa is a lot more than what people might think it is.â€

â€• Vincent Pierce, 31, music teacher

â€œWhen I first moved here, it was not my ideal place to live, but after being here, you fall in love with the people. Theyâ€™re salt of the earth.â€

â€• Debi Hays, 60, self-employed

â€œIâ€™m a first-generation college student ... I actually love it. It reminds of the small community I grew up in. It feels like home for me, even though Iâ€™m six hours away from my family.â€

â€• Jefember Villela, 23, student/media coordinator

â€œItâ€™s home ... I fell in love with Odessa when I was a kid because Iâ€™ve always felt comfortable.â€

â€• Jacyree Webbs, 19, sales/student
TITLE: 'Itâ€™s Something Different': Meet The People Of Odessa, Texas

SUMMARY:
Blake Lively, is that really you?
The actress was spotted filming her new spy thriller movie "The Rhythm Section" in Dublin, Ireland, over the weekend looking totally unrecognizable.
(We haven't seen a transformation so drastic since Margot Robbie was spotted in costume as Queen Elizabeth I.)
Gone are Lively's long and luscious blond tresses and red carpet dresses.
Instead, she was seen sporting a shaggy cropped hairdo, plain, baggy clothes and little (if any) makeup.
TEXT:
Blake Lively, is that really you?

The actress was spotted filming her new spy thriller movie "The Rhythm Section" in Dublin, Ireland, over the weekend looking totally unrecognizable. (We haven't seen a transformation so drastic since Margot Robbie was spotted in costume as Queen Elizabeth I.)

Gone are Lively's long and luscious blond tresses and red carpet dresses. Instead, she was seen sporting a shaggy cropped hairdo, plain, baggy clothes and little (if any) makeup.

Take a look for yourself:
TITLE: Blake Lively Spotted Filming New Movie 'The Rhythm Section' In Dublin

SUMMARY:
MONTREAL â€” Greater Montreal homes sold more quickly in October as continued strong demand propelled average prices seven per cent higher, the area's real estate board said Monday.
"The single-family home and plex markets are becoming increasingly favourable to sellers, as selling times for these property categories are falling," said Mathieu Cousineau, president of the Greater Montreal Real Estate Board.
Single family homes sold last month were on the market on average for 78 days, almost two weeks less than a year ago.
Last month was the most active October in eight years, the real estate board said.
That compared to $780,104 in Greater Toronto, up 2.3 per cent from the prior year and $1.04 million in Greater Vancouver, up 12.4 per cent.
TEXT:
A home is put up for sale in downtown Montreal, July 14, 2009.

MONTREAL â€” Greater Montreal homes sold more quickly in October as continued strong demand propelled average prices seven per cent higher, the area's real estate board said Monday.

"The single-family home and plex markets are becoming increasingly favourable to sellers, as selling times for these property categories are falling," said Mathieu Cousineau, president of the Greater Montreal Real Estate Board.

Single family homes sold last month were on the market on average for 78 days, almost two weeks less than a year ago.

Buildings with two to five units sold three days quicker at 81 days. Condominiums took the longest to sell at 103 days, but that was 17 days fewer than in October 2016. That signals a balanced condo market, said Cousineau.

Most active October in eight years

The number of homes sold in the month increased seven per cent to 3,270, led by a 13 per cent increase in condo sales and three per cent for single homes.

Last month was the most active October in eight years, the real estate board said.

The strong activity came ahead of the federal government's plans to tighten mortgage requirements.

The Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions will implement new lending guidelines at the beginning of next year. Among the changes being considered is a requirement that homebuyers who do not require mortgage insurance still have to show they can make their payments if interest rates rise.

Paul Cardinal of the Quebec Federation of Real Estate Boards has attributed monthly housing gains this year to strong job creation, consumer confidence and foreign migration.

A home is put up for sale in downtown Montreal, July 14, 2009.

Sales on the island of Montreal, which accounted for 43 per cent of area transactions, grew 11 per cent.

Almost half the sales were for condos, which grew 14 per cent.

Canada's second-largest city and the region surrounding it remain a real estate bargain as the average price grew seven per cent to $367,512 from $347,281 a year ago. The average price on the Island of Montreal, which includes suburbs, rose 6.1 per cent to $462,516.

That compared to $780,104 in Greater Toronto, up 2.3 per cent from the prior year and $1.04 million in Greater Vancouver, up 12.4 per cent.

Also On HuffPost:
TITLE: Greater Montreal Homes Are Selling Faster Than They Were A Year Ago

TEXT:
Si eres fan de los royals, de seguro tienes fantasÃ­as de cÃ³mo serÃ­a asistir a una boda real. Y ahora que el prÃ­ncipe Harry y Meghan Markle estÃ¡n a punto de unirse en matrimonio, seguramente tus fantasÃ­as estÃ¡n a todo lo que dan.

Pero si bien uno sÃ³lo puede imaginarse lo que es ser invitado a una boda asÃ­, el periodista Duncan Larcombe conoce de primera mano quÃ© tan glamoroso es un acto asÃ­.

AsÃ­, mientras no despegÃ¡bamos la mirada de la tele el dÃ­a en que Kate Middleton y el prÃ­ncipe William se dieron el sÃ­ en abril de 2011, Larcombe de hecho figurÃ³ entre las 1,900 personas que asistieron a la ceremonia nupcial en la AbadÃ­a de Westminster.

El ex editor de realeza para The Sun, fue uno de los seis periodistas que asistiÃ³ como invitado. "Nos dijeron unas dos o tres semanas por anticipado que serÃ­amos invitados, pero que no lo podÃ­amos decir a nadie", dijo a Elle UK en una reciente entrevista. "No querÃ­a que se esparciera esto entre otros periodistas".

AsÃ­ que, Â¿quÃ© se sintiÃ³ al estar entre tantos royals en esa ceremonia? De acuerdo con Larcombe, fue tan surreal como cualquiera lo imagina.

"Fue una experiencia muy extraÃ±a, algo asÃ­ como sentarse en el museo de cera de Madame Tussauds, pero con estatuas parlantes", dijo. "Fue una de las experiencias mÃ¡s increÃ­bles de toda mi vida. Es darse cuenta de que la historia se escribe frente a tus propios ojos.

"No se parece a ninguna de las otras bodas a las que he ido", aÃ±adiÃ³. "Si te gusta ver a la gente famosa, probablemente no hay nada mejor para ello que una boda real. No hay lugar que contenta a tantos famosos y miembros de la realeza bajo un solo techo".

Larcombe tambiÃ©n pudo ser testigo de momentos francos por parte de los royals, incluyendo cÃ³mo el prÃ­ncipe Harry trataba de componerse a sÃ­ mismo al lado de su hermano Harry antes de la ceremonia. "Se veÃ­a completamente aterrado", dijo el periodista, y luego, el silencio total que llenÃ³ la iglesia cuando la Duquesa de Cambridge finalmente entrÃ³.

"Todo lo que podÃ­amos escuchar eran los ecos de la muchedumbre de afuera", dijo.

Si bien Larscombe seÃ±ala que hubo una espera interminable antes de que iniciara la ceremonia nupcial, el evento bien que valiÃ³ la pena. No sÃ³lo vio cÃ³mo se escribÃ­a la historia ante sus ojos, sino que se demostrÃ³ que cada invitado recibÃ­a un trato de iguales, sin importar quÃ© tan famoso (o no tan famoso) es.

"Fue muy claro en la boda que no importaba si eras el sultÃ¡n de Brunei o un tipo que se ha cruzado en (la Real Academia de) Sandhurst con William, o una estrella de Hollywood... todos tuvimos que llegar temprano", explicÃ³, aÃ±adiendo que la Reina fue la Ãºltima en llegar antes de la novia. "Supongo que para alguien como Sir Elton John, a quien le encanta ser el centro de la atenciÃ³n, eso fue algo muy humillante".

Aunque hay mucha emociÃ³n por el eventual compromiso y boda de Harry, su ceremonia nupcial serÃ¡ muy diferente a la de su hermano dado que William es el segundo en la lÃ­nea para heredar el trono y Harry es el quinto (y serÃ¡ el sexto cuando el tercer bebÃ© de William y Catherine nazca). Esto significa que la boda con Markle serÃ¡ un tanto mÃ¡s informal.

El mes pasado una fuente cercana a Harry dijo al US Weekly que se espera que sea una boda de mucho mÃ¡s bajo perfil.

"La pompa y el esplendor es lo menos que Harry quiere", dijo la fuente a ese sitio. "Puedo adivinar que se casarÃ¡ en la Capilla de San Jorge en el castillo de Windsor. Con ello, no serÃ­a un circo para los medios y le darÃ­a al evento el sentido de privacidad que Harry tanto quiere".

SÃ³lo el tiempo dirÃ¡ cÃ³mo serÃ¡ la real boda de Harry. De nuestra parte, lo que decimos es que Â¡ojalÃ¡ que nuestra invitaciÃ³n no se pierda en el correo!
TITLE: Un periodista britÃ¡nico revela lo que se siente asistir a una boda real

TEXT:
Die Wirkung von GlÃ¼ck auf den Menschen ist hinreichend erforscht - die Wirkung der Natur dagegen weniger. Das Ã¤ndert sich allerdings gerade, was nicht zuletzt auf BÃ¼cher wie â€Das geheime Leben der BÃ¤ume", â€Gebrauchsanweisung fÃ¼r den Wald", â€Das geheime Netzwerk der Natur" des schreibenden FÃ¶rsters Peter Wohlleben zurÃ¼ckzufÃ¼hren ist. WÃ¤lder sind fÃ¼r ihn nicht nur â€Holzfabriken und Rohstofflager", sondern auch LebensrÃ¤ume fÃ¼r viele Tier- und Pflanzenarten, die miteinander verwoben und voneinander abhÃ¤ngig sind. Immer, wenn sie sich artgerecht entfalten kÃ¶nnen, bieten sie Schutz und Erholung. Mit seinem Engagement setzt er ein hoffnungsvolles Zeichen fÃ¼r die Zukunft, dass das geheime Leben der WÃ¤lder und der BÃ¤ume weiterhin stattfindet und auch unsere Nachfahren noch staunend zwischen den BÃ¤umen spazieren kÃ¶nnen.

Der Aufenthalt in der Natur verbessert die Stimmung und entlastet die Atemwege. Deshalb ist es wichtig, in die Stadtbebauung mehr GrÃ¼n zu integrieren - das beeinflusst positiv Herzschlag und das vegetative Nervensystem. â€Es geht dabei nicht um Sauerstoff, sondern offensichtlich um einen Reiz, der unser vegetatives Nervensystem runterfahren lÃ¤sst", sagt Peter Falkei, Direktor der Klinik und Poliklinik fÃ¼r Psychiatrie und Psychotherapie am Klinikum der Ludwig-Maximilians-UniversitÃ¤t (LMU) in MÃ¼nchen. Wenn man durch einen Wald geht, werden die neuronalen Netze â€heruntergefahren". Er vermutet, dass dies mit einem GefÃ¼hl von Geborgenheit zu tun hat, einem Schutz vor LÃ¤rm und Stress. Auch regenerieren sich Hirnareale, die zustÃ¤ndig fÃ¼r Aufmerksamkeit und Konzentration sind, wÃ¤hrend eines Spaziergangs, der uns hilft, wieder ins Gleichgewicht zu kommen in der SchrÃ¤glage der Welt.

Foto: Dr. Alexandra Hildebrandt

StÃ¤dte machen nervÃ¶ser und lassen Menschen schlechter schlafen. Auch Lichtverschmutzung ist ein enormes Gesundheitsrisiko. Im Gehirn kommen die beiden Schaltstellen Mandelkern und Cingulum ins Spiel: Der Mandelkern reagiert auf Dinge, die er nicht kennt und nicht verorten kann; das Cingulum macht den Relevanzcheck: Ist etwas wichtig fÃ¼r die eigene Person oder nicht? Aktuelle Studien belegen, dass beide bei Menschen, die in StÃ¤dten mit mehr als 100.000 Einwohnern aufwachsen, aktiver sind, was zu einer Grundunruhe der StÃ¤dter fÃ¼hrt, â€einer Art unproduktiven Aufmerksamkeit" (Falkei). Meistens sind Depressionen oder Angsterkrankungen auf private Stressfaktoren und berufliche Probleme zurÃ¼ckzufÃ¼hren.

Viele Menschen greifen dann auf Antidepressiva zurÃ¼ck. Laut Depressionsatlas der deutschen Techniker Krankenkasse hat sich zwischen 2000 und 2013 die verschriebene Tagesmenge an Antidepressiva verdreifacht. 2015 zahlten die gesetzlichen Krankenversicherungen dafÃ¼r rund 750 Millionen Euro an die Pharmaindustrie.

Statt auf Medikamente zu setzen verordnen Ã„rzte in Japan ihren Patienten Waldtherapien, denn bewusstes Gehen durch den Wald ist gesundheitsfÃ¶rdernd. Inzwischen hat der Trend auch Deutschland erreicht. Auf Usedom darf sich seit September 2017 ein Wald â€Kur- und Heilwald" nennen.

FÃ¼r 94 Prozent der erwachsenen Deutschen gehÃ¶ren die Natur und insbesondere der Wald zu einem guten Leben. Das ist das Ergebnis einer Studie des Bundesamtes fÃ¼r Naturschutz (BfN) zum Naturbewusstsein der Deutschen, die 2016 erschien. Die NÃ¤he zur Natur ist mit einer grÃ¶ÃŸeren Lebenszufriedenheit verbunden.

BÃ¤ume haben bis heute nur deshalb Ã¼berlebt, weil sie eine enorme (Widerstands-)Kraft bzw. Resilienz und genetische Vielfalt innerhalb einer Art aufweisen. â€Fest und stark ist nur der Baum, der unablÃ¤ssig Winden ausgesetzt war, denn im Kampf festigen und verstÃ¤rken sich seine Wurzeln", schrieb schon der rÃ¶mische Philosoph Seneca. Wo sich BÃ¤ume wieder erneuern, erleben sich auch die Menschen als selbst regulierendes Prinzip. BÃ¤ume, die bis heute einzigartig sind, dienten den Menschen als Heiligtum, als Nahrungs- und Inspirationsquelle. Prominente Baumliebhaber waren Goethe, Beethoven, Abraham Lincoln, Bismarck, Hermann Hesse, Kurt Tucholsky, Winston Churchill, Ruth Maria Kubitschek oder Michael Gorbatschow.

Der Wald hat heute neben der Holzproduktion seine grÃ¶ÃŸte Bedeutung im Klimaschutz - nÃ¤mlich die (Ã¼ber)lebensnotwendige CO2-Sequestrierung. Deshalb muss eine nachhaltige Optimierung zwischen der Holzproduktion und der Klimawirkung gesucht werden. Viele groÃŸe private Waldbesitzer in Deutschland haben (hÃ¤ufig im Gegensatz zu den Staatsforsten) seit langem einen hohen Holzvorrat im Wald angestrebt. Damit verbunden ist die Befolgung einer dynamischen Nachhaltigkeitsregel (Holz + CO2-Sequestrierung). In absehbarer Zukunft muss viel weniger Holz geschlagen werden, denn fÃ¼r den Klimaschutz ist es zwingend, die Biomasse im Wald mindestens bis ins Jahr 2150 so hoch wie mÃ¶glich anwachsen zu lassen.

Der Begriff Nachhaltigkeit kommt aus der Forstwirtschaft und bezeichnet die Nutzung eines regenerierbaren Systems, so dass es in seinen wesentlichen Eigenschaften erhalten bleibt und sich auf natÃ¼rliche Weise erneuern kann. Der US-amerikanische Songwriter, Country- und Folk-SÃ¤nger Songwriter John Denver grÃ¼ndete die Organisation â€Plant It 2000" zur Wiederaufforstung hunderttausender BÃ¤ume, der Unternehmer und Umweltaktivist Douglas Tompkins, GrÃ¼nder und ehemaliger Chef der Textilmarken The North Face und Esprit Holdings Limited, kaufte ein groÃŸes Gebiet in Argentinien und Chile auf, um Nationalparks zu schaffen. Und der ehemalige Chefdirigent der Berliner Philharmoniker Claudio Abbado ermÃ¶glichte mit zwei Konzerthonoraren die Anpflanzung von 90.000 BÃ¤umen in seiner Heimatstadt Mailand.

In seinem Privatgarten am Landsitz Highgrove spricht Prinz Charles regelmÃ¤ÃŸig mit seinen BÃ¤umen und behandelt sie fast wie PersÃ¶nlichkeiten. Zudem setzt er sich seit Jahrzehnten mit seinen Stiftungen fÃ¼r Naturschutz und Artenvielfalt ein.

Als der Reformator Martin Luther im April 1539 in seinem Garten die BÃ¤ume betrachtete, sprach er: â€Gelobt sei Gott, der SchÃ¶pfer, der aus toten verstorbenen Kreaturen im Lenz alles wieder lebendig macht!" Er liebte BÃ¤ume aber nicht nur wegen ihrer Erhabenheit und SchÃ¶nheit, sondern auch wegen ihres nachhaltigen Nutzens. Sein berÃ¼hmter Satz â€Wenn ich wÃ¼sste, dass morgen die Welt unterginge, wÃ¼rde ich heute noch ein ApfelbÃ¤umchen pflanzen.", lÃ¤sst sich zwar nicht belegbar nachweisen, weil der erste schriftliche Nachweis erst in einem Rundbrief der hessischen Kirche aus dem Jahre 1944 zu finden ist - dennoch wÃ¤re diese Aussage sicher in seinem Sinne gewesen.

Ein immerwÃ¤hrender Neuanfang.

Foto: Dr. Alexandra Hildebrandt

Literatur:

Peter Wohlleben: Das geheime Leben der BÃ¤ume. Was sie fÃ¼hlen, wie sie kommunizieren - die Entdeckung einer verborgenen Welt. Ludwig Verlag MÃ¼nchen 2015.

Claudia Silber und Alexandra Hildebrandt: Gut zu wissen... wie es grÃ¼ner geht: Die wichtigsten Tipps fÃ¼r ein bewusstes Leben von Amazon Media EU S.Ã  r.l. Kindle Edition 2017.

Das Grundrauschen. Interview mit Peter Falkai von Anna Hoben. In: SÃ¼ddeutsche Zeitung (4./5.2017), S. 85.

Menschen Ã¼ber BÃ¤ume. Gedanken, Begebenheiten und Anekdoten aus vier Jahrtausenden. Zusammengestellt und herausgegeben von Dietmar Olonscheck. Oekom Verlag, MÃ¼nchen 2017.

Wolfgang Schmidbauer: Raubbau an der Seele. Psychogramm einer Ã¼berforderten Gesellschaft. Oekom Verlag, MÃ¼nchen 2017.

TITLE: Die Gesundmacher: Neuronale Netze und das geheime Netzwerk der Natur

SUMMARY:
Often associated with veterans returning from war zones, Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) may not seem like something that might affect a child.
Like adults, all children will have different reactions to a traumatic event, and how they react may depend on a combination of their age, personality and previous life experience.
The charity PTSD UK says that at the most basic level, PTSD is a â€œmemory filing errorâ€ caused by a traumatic event, which and can affect anyone, regardless of their age.
â€œYou may notice that they are less able to concentrate or they become easily distracted,â€ said Dr Rosan.
â€œThere may also be changes in their behaviour such as becoming jumpy, finding it hard to sleep, having temper tantrums or being disobedient, or being overly clingy compared to usual,â€ said Dr Rosan.
TEXT:
And the risk of them subsequently developing the anxiety disorder PTSD is particularly high if the childâ€™s family is facing poverty, unemployment or housing issues.

But actually more than two thirds of children in the UK are likely to have experienced a traumatic event by the age of 16, according to chartered clinical psychologist Dr Camilla Rosan, who helped to write the guide for social workers looking after the families affected by the Grenfell Tower fire .

Often associated with veterans returning from war zones, Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) may not seem like something that might affect a child.

Like adults, all children will have different reactions to a traumatic event, and how they react may depend on a combination of their age, personality and previous life experience.

But children are unlikely to know that they are suffering, and so will require parents to help them understand what they are going through.

Why might a child suffer from PTSD?

The charity PTSD UK says that at the most basic level, PTSD is a â€œmemory filing errorâ€ caused by a traumatic event, which and can affect anyone, regardless of their age.

In fact one in three teenagers who survives a serious car crash and 40% of people who have lost a loved one suddenly will experience PTSD.

According to PTSD UK the defining characteristic of a traumatic event is whether or not it has the â€œcapacity to provoke fear, helplessness, or horror in response to the threat of injury or deathâ€ so consider the event in those terms.

Young people are just as vulnerable to these triggers as adults.

â€œPTSD can occur after directly or indirectly experiencing a traumatic event that puts you or someone close to you at risk of serious harm or death,â€ said Dr Rosan, programme lead at the Mental Health Foundation.

â€œThis can be anything from a road accident, to experiencing or witnessing violence or human accidents.â€

What are the signs of PTSD in a child?

As with adults, the way children react to a trauma is likely to be individual to them as a person, but there are some tell-tale symptoms of PTSD that parents can be alert to.

Dr Rosan advised that it is likely children, who are older than toddlers, will experience a physical response, with symptoms such as an increased heart rate, sweating, rapid breathing and changes in appetite.

Your child might also become preoccupied with thoughts or images of the event or start experiencing nightmares and worrying that it will happen again.

â€œYou may notice that they are less able to concentrate or they become easily distracted,â€ said Dr Rosan.

â€œA sudden onset of intense emotions is also to be expected â€“ such as fearfulness, increased anxiety, anger or irritability.â€

For younger children, physical symptoms might not be reported in these terms and instead they might tell you they have a headache or stomach ache.

â€œThere may also be changes in their behaviour such as becoming jumpy, finding it hard to sleep, having temper tantrums or being disobedient, or being overly clingy compared to usual,â€ said Dr Rosan.

â€œRegressive behaviours are common, such as a resurgence of bedwetting or thumb-sucking.â€

If you are worried your child is displaying any of these behaviours, visit your GP.
TITLE: Post Traumatic Stress Disorder In Children: These Are The Symptoms Parents Need To Look Out For

The incident came just days before the premiere of the Showtime seriesâ€™ new season.
Angela Weiss via Getty Images Ethan Cutkosky pictured in 2014.
Showtime Ethan Cutkosky and William H. Macy in "Shameless."

TEXT:
Actor Ethan Cutkosky, who plays reformed troublemaker Carl Gallagher on â€œShameless,â€ was arrested last week for suspicion of driving under the influence, TMZ and CBS Los Angeles have reported.

The incident came just days before the premiere of the Showtime seriesâ€™ new season.

Cutkosky, 18, was pulled over on Thursday in Los Angeles after police noticed his orange BMW began straddling lanes and was arrested after failing to pass a roadside sobriety test. He was released from jail on $5,000 bail with a court appearance scheduled later in the month, per CBS.

A representative for Cutkosky did not immediately return HuffPostâ€™s request for comment.

Angela Weiss via Getty Images Ethan Cutkosky pictured in 2014.

TMZ notes that Cutkosky apparently admitted to smoking marijuana earlier in the night after police noticed a smell coming from the vehicle.

Authorities are currently awaiting the results of a blood test to draw up charges.

Showtime Ethan Cutkosky and William H. Macy in "Shameless."

Working as an actor since he was 7 years old, Cutkosky has starred on the critically acclaimed Showtime series over eight seasons, growing up on screen with the rest of the Gallagher kids. Most notably, the show stars William H. Macy as the familyâ€™s alcoholic father and Emmy Rossum as the eldest sister trying to keep the clan above water.
TITLE: 'Shameless' Star Ethan Cutkosky Arrested For DUI

Tuve que tener huevos", detalla la actriz en su relato.

Ryder protagonizarÃ­a Beettlejuice unos aÃ±os despuÃ©s de esto, con solo 17 aÃ±os, y segÃºn se puede leer en la historia, no le costÃ³ planear su venganza una vez que logrÃ³ la fama.
Ella respondiÃ³ que recordaba 'algo', le dije que era yo y la mandÃ© a tomar por culo", concluye.
TEXT:
Numerosos actores de Hollywood han sufrido acoso escolar. Charlize Theron, Jack Nicholson o Demi Moore han sido vÃ­ctimas de los matones de instituto. A esos nombres se suma Winona Ryder que, segÃºn relata la actriz en su biografÃ­a, recibiÃ³ una paliza en el instituto por el simple hecho de llevar una cazadora de chico. Ahora, una usuaria de Twitter ha recuperado su historia y se ha vuelto viral.

"Llevaba una vieja sudadera de chico deI EjÃ©rcito de SalvaciÃ³n", recuerda la actriz. "Fui al baÃ±o y escuchÃ© 'Hey, maricÃ³n'. Entonces me estamparon la cabeza en una taquilla, me caÃ­ al suelo y empezaron a patearme. Tuve que tener huevos", detalla la actriz en su relato. SegÃºn la publicaciÃ³n, el desenlace de estos acontecimientos fue bastante curioso ya que la expulsaron a ella en lugar de a los matones.

Ryder protagonizarÃ­a Beettlejuice unos aÃ±os despuÃ©s de esto, con solo 17 aÃ±os, y segÃºn se puede leer en la historia, no le costÃ³ planear su venganza una vez que logrÃ³ la fama. "Al tiempo, fui a una cafeterÃ­a y me encontrÃ© con una de las chicas que me pateÃ³. Me dijo: 'Winona, Winona, Â¿me puedes firmar un autÃ³grafo?'. Entonces le dije: 'Â¿Te acuerdas de mÃ­? Â¿Te acuerdas que en sÃ©ptimo pateaste a una niÃ±a?' Ella respondiÃ³ que recordaba 'algo', le dije que era yo y la mandÃ© a tomar por culo", concluye.

El relato original del tuit â€”que ha alcanzado en dos dÃ­as mÃ¡s de 160.000 retuits y 500.000 me gustaâ€” detalla que esto ocurriÃ³ el tercer dÃ­a de clase de sÃ©ptimo curso en el instituto Kenilworth de Petaluma (California, EEUU) y que terminÃ³ con las costillas fracturadas y seis puntos en la cabeza.

Ryder llevaba entonces el pelo corto y usaba ropa para niÃ±os debido la influencia de las pelÃ­culas de gÃ¡nsteres de entonces como Bugsy Malone (1976), por lo que cree que los matones pensaban que era un chico gay. Aunque, a pesar de aclararles que era una chica, estos siguieron molestÃ¡ndola.

Al protagonizar la pelÃ­cula de Tim Burton pensÃ³: "Oh, es la pelÃ­cula nÃºmero uno. Esto harÃ¡ que las cosas mejoren en la escuela". Sin embargo, solo lo empeorÃ³: "Me llamaron bruja".

Esta agresiÃ³n no fue la Ãºnica sufrida por la actriz, que en 2013 contÃ³ en una entrevista en V Magazine que le pegaron una paliza y la llamaron "maricÃ³n", lo que hizo que dejara el instituto y se apuntara al Conservatorio de Teatro de San Francisco.

Cuarenta aÃ±os despuÃ©s, la actriz sigue cosechando Ã©xitos con su estilo personal, de hecho en el Ãºltimo aÃ±o ha sido nominada al Globo de Oro a Mejor actriz de televisiÃ³n por su papel de Joyce en Stranger Things.
TITLE: La venganza de Winona Ryder a los matones de su instituto se vuelve viral

"Ich fÃ¼hlte kaum Tritte und die, die ich bemerkte, waren sehr sanft â€“ es war nicht normalâ€œ, sagte sie dem amerikanischen Nachrichtenportal "USA Todayâ€œ.
SchlieÃŸlich konnte mithilfe von Spenden auch die App, die laut den GrÃ¼nderinnen auf wissenschaftlichen und medizinischen Erkenntnissen basiert, entwickelt werden.
Sie unterstÃ¼tzt die werdenden MÃ¼tter dabei, tÃ¤glich in einem bestimmten Zeitabschnitt die Bewegungen ihres Babys zu zÃ¤hlen und zu Ã¼berwachen.
Price hofft, dass sie mithilfe der App und AufklÃ¤rung der MÃ¼tter Ã¤hnliche Erfolge bei der Senkung der Totgeburtenrate erzielen kann.
Interessierte MÃ¼tter kÃ¶nnen sich die App auf der Webseite der Organisation kostenlos herunterladen.
TEXT:
Diese App von MÃ¼ttern hat in zehn Wochen drei Babys gerettet - mit einer ganz einfachen Methode. | DaniloAndjus via Getty Images

Emily Eekhoff bemerkte, dass sich ihr ungeborenes Baby plÃ¶tzlich anders in ihrem Bauch bewegt

Sie alarmierte die Ã„rzte gerade noch rechtzeitig und konnte so ihr Baby retten

Die App Count the Kicks half ihr dabei, zu merken, dass etwas mit ihrer Tochter nicht stimmte

Die junge Mutter Emily Eekhoff ist Ã¼berzeugt: Ohne eine App wÃ¤re ihr Baby jetzt nicht mehr am Leben.

Die 26-JÃ¤hrige aus Des Moines im US-Bundesstaat Iowa nutzte wÃ¤hrend ihrer Schwangerschaft die App Count the Kicks (auf Deutsch: ZÃ¤hlt die Tritte) - sie hilft MÃ¼ttern im letzten Trimester dabei, die AktivitÃ¤t ihrer Babys im Bauch zu Ã¼berwachen.

Wenn einer werdenden Mutter auffÃ¤llt, dass sich das Baby auf einmal ungewÃ¶hnlich still verhÃ¤lt, kann das auf gefÃ¤hrliche Komplikationen hinweisen.

Ohne die App und die Aufmerksamkeit ihrer Mutter hÃ¤tte Ruby nicht Ã¼berlebt

Als sich die hochschwangere Eekhoff vergangenen FrÃ¼hling eines Abends hinsetzte, um mithilfe der App die Bewegungen ihres Babys zu zÃ¤hlen, spÃ¼rte sie, dass etwas anders war als sonst. "Ich fÃ¼hlte kaum Tritte und die, die ich bemerkte, waren sehr sanft â€“ es war nicht normalâ€œ, sagte sie dem amerikanischen Nachrichtenportal "USA Todayâ€œ.

Auch Techniken, die das Baby im Bauch zu mehr Bewegungen animieren sollen, brachten keine VerÃ¤nderung. Beunruhigt fuhren die Eltern ins Krankenhaus. Dort stellten die Ã„rzte fest, dass das Baby in groÃŸen Schwierigkeiten war und der Mediziner Neil Mandsager, der auf Risikoschwangerschaften spezialisiert ist, leitete einen Not-Kaiserschnitt ein.

Denn bei der kleinen Ruby hatte sich die Nabelschnur dreimal um ihr Genick gewickelt. Die Ã„rzte sind der Meinung, dass sie so keinen Tag mehr im Bauch ihrer Mutter Ã¼berlebt hÃ¤tte. Doch dank der schnellen Hilfe hat es das kleine MÃ¤dchen auf die Welt geschafft - und entwickelt sich prÃ¤chtig.

Arzt Mandsager kennt die App und empfiehlt sie allen werdenden MÃ¼ttern: â€œDiese App ist ein schlagkrÃ¤ftiges Instrument fÃ¼r MÃ¼tter im letzten Trimester. Wir ermutigen alle MÃ¼tter, diese App herunterzuladen, wenn sie in der 28. Woche sind â€“ bei Risikoschwangerschaften auch gern schon ab der 26. Woche.â€œ

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Sie hat ihr Baby verloren - mit diesen Fotos macht eine junge Frau anderen Betroffenen Mut

"Wir wissen von drei Babys, die wir diesen Sommer gerettet habenâ€œ

Im Bundesstaat Iowa empfehlen in einer Ã¶ffentlichen Kampagne viele KrankenhÃ¤user und GynÃ¤kologen, die Bewegungen des Babys im Bauch zu zÃ¤hlen â€“ auch mithilfe von Count the Kicks, das man kostenlos downloaden kann.

Emily Price, GeschÃ¤ftsfÃ¼hrerin von Count the Kicks, sagte der HuffPost: "Wir wissen von drei Babys, die wir diesen Sommer gerettet haben, da ihre MÃ¼tter die App genutzt haben und zum Arzt gegangen sind, als ihnen VerÃ¤nderungen bei den Bewegungen ihrer Babys aufgefallen sind.â€œ

ZurÃ¼ck geht das Projekt auf fÃ¼nf Mutter, die alle aus Iowa stammen und eine Fehl- oder Totgeburt erlitten haben. Nach dieser traumatischen Erfahrung wollten die Frauen verhindern, dass andere Familien das gleiche Schicksal erleben mÃ¼ssen.

Die MÃ¼tter stieÃŸen bei der Recherche auf ein Projekt aus Norwegen: Dort konnte in mehreren KrankenhÃ¤usern nach einer Ã¶ffentlichen Gesundheitskampagne die Rate der Totgeburten um 30 Prozent gesenkt werden, wie mehrere Studien zeigen.

In der Kampagne wurde schwangeren Frauen nahegelegt, ab dem letzten Schwangerschaftsdrittel die Tritte ihrer Babys tÃ¤glich zu zÃ¤hlen und regelmÃ¤ÃŸig zu den Vorsorgeuntersuchungen zu gehen.

Die Rate der Totgeburten sank in Iowa um 23 Prozent

Davon inspiriert starteten die MÃ¼tter 2009 "Healthy Birth Dayâ€œ, eine Non-Profit-Organisation, die sich mit UnterstÃ¼tzung der Regierung in Iowa mit den KrankenhÃ¤usern und GynÃ¤kologen vernetzte und BroschÃ¼ren und Informationen an werdende MÃ¼tter verteilte.

SchlieÃŸlich konnte mithilfe von Spenden auch die App, die laut den GrÃ¼nderinnen auf wissenschaftlichen und medizinischen Erkenntnissen basiert, entwickelt werden. Sie unterstÃ¼tzt die werdenden MÃ¼tter dabei, tÃ¤glich in einem bestimmten Zeitabschnitt die Bewegungen ihres Babys zu zÃ¤hlen und zu Ã¼berwachen.

Bisher haben laut Price 45.000 Frauen die App heruntergeladen - weltweit. Am weitesten verbreitet ist Count the Kicks allerdings in Iowa.

Seit der EinfÃ¼hrung von Count the Kicks sank die Rate der Totgeburten in dem Bundesstaat um 26 Prozent â€“ einen Erfolg, den Price der Kampagne ihrer Organisation zuschreibt.

Die GeschÃ¤ftsfÃ¼hrerin sagt: "Manchmal ist das ZÃ¤hlen der Tritte im Bauch das einzige Anzeichen und das frÃ¼heste Anzeichen, das etwas schief lÃ¤uft.â€œ Bis zu sechzehn Babys wurden bisher mit dieser Methode gerettet, wie die Organisation berichtet.

â¨ Mehr zum Thema: Darf ich mich Mutter nennen?

2000 Sternenkinder pro Jahr

In Deutschland kommen auf 1000 Neugeborene 2,4 Totgeburten â€“ unser Land hat damit eine der niedrigsten Raten der Welt. Das bedeutet, dass es bei uns pro Jahr 2000 sogenannte Sternenkinder gibt.

Die Ursache dafÃ¼r, dass die Babys noch im Bauch der Mutter sterben, kÃ¶nnen Probleme mit der Plazenta oder der Nabelschnur sein - bei Ã¼ber 30 Prozent der FÃ¤lle bleibt der Grund allerdings unklar.

Zur Vorbeugung einer Totgeburt empfehlen die Ã„rzte auch bei uns, auf die Bewegungen des Kindes im Bauch zu achten und regelmÃ¤ÃŸig zur Vorsorge zu gehen. Bei vaginalen Blutungen sollten Schwangere sofort einen Arzt aufsuchen.

AufklÃ¤rung soll helfen, die Rate noch weiter zu senken

Nicht zu verwechseln sind Totgeburten mit Fehlgeburten - diese sind vor allem im ersten Trimester sehr hÃ¤ufig. Ã„rzte schÃ¤tzen, dass in Deutschland 30 Prozent der Schwangerschaften mit einer Fehlgeburt enden. Ursache sind dabei genetische StÃ¶rungen und fehlerhafte Zellteilungen beim Embryo, die eine Weiterentwicklung des Babys verhindern.

Dagegen kann die Methode des Tritte ZÃ¤hlens natÃ¼rlich leider nicht helfen. Sie richtet sich ausschlieÃŸlich an Schwangere im letzten Trimester. Die Hoffnung ist, dass die Ã„rzte das Baby in manchen FÃ¤llen â€“ wie bei Problemen mit der Nabelschnur - noch retten kÃ¶nnen, wenn die MÃ¼tter eine VerÃ¤nderung der Kindsbewegungen bemerken.

Wie in Deutschland ist die Zahl der Totgeburten in den USA etwas hÃ¶her als die Zahl der Kinder, die an dem PlÃ¶tzlichen Kindstod (SIDS) sterben. Hier haben zahlreiche AufklÃ¤rungsprogramme dabei geholfen, dass der Befund in den letzten Jahren gesunken ist â€“ in Deutschland in den letzten zwei Jahrzehnten sogar um etwa 90 Prozent.

Price hofft, dass sie mithilfe der App und AufklÃ¤rung der MÃ¼tter Ã¤hnliche Erfolge bei der Senkung der Totgeburtenrate erzielen kann.

Interessierte MÃ¼tter kÃ¶nnen sich die App auf der Webseite der Organisation kostenlos herunterladen.

(best)
TITLE: Eine App hat in zehn Wochen drei Babys gerettet - durch eine ganz einfache Methode

Weary of simple pop music spats, Taylor Swift now has a new feuding partner: the ACLU.
Swift as some sort of white supremacist figurehead, which is a baseless fiction masquerading as fact and completely misrepresents Ms.
Swift," Briggs wrote.
The letter also defends Swift's political silence in the last presidential election as a personal choice, as she has "no obligation to campaign for any particular political candidate or broadcast her political views."
Swift has yet to respond to the ACLU's letter, as well as HuffPost's request for comment.
TEXT:
Weary of simple pop music spats, Taylor Swift now has a new feuding partner: the ACLU.

The singer has landed in the watchdog organization's crosshairs after her lawyer sent an intimidating letter to the website PopFront regarding a recent article about Swift's popularity among white supremacists.

In a piece titled, "Swiftly to the alt-right: Taylor subtly gets the lower case kkk in formation," writer Meghan Herning argues that Swift's new single "Look What You Made Me Do" serves as a "subtle, quiet white support of a racial hierarchy" by positioning the singer alongside the history of the eugenics movement and the rise of neo-Nazis.

William J. Briggs, a lawyer representing Swift, wrote in a letter to Herning that her PopFront article is a "provably false and defamatory story" that will result in a lawsuit if the website refuses to issue a retraction or take down the post.

"It appears to be a malicious attack against Ms. Swift that goes to great lengths to portray Ms. Swift as some sort of white supremacist figurehead, which is a baseless fiction masquerading as fact and completely misrepresents Ms. Swift," Briggs wrote.

The letter also defends Swift's political silence in the last presidential election as a personal choice, as she has "no obligation to campaign for any particular political candidate or broadcast her political views."

Herning shared the letter with the ACLU, which is now defending the blogger against any legal threats against her, calling Briggs' claims "meritless." In the eyes of the organization, the article is a "mix of political speech and critical commentary" that falls within the protections of the First Amendment.

"This is a completely unsupported attempt to suppress constitutionally protected speech," Michael Risher, an attorney for ACLU of Northern California, said in a press release.

"Intimidation tactics like these are unacceptable," Matt Cagle, another attorney with the organization, added. "Not in her wildest dreams can Ms. Swift use copyright law to suppress this exposure of a threat to constitutionally protected speech."

Swift has taken legal action against claims of this nature before. The singer has been heralded as a white supremacist hero in the dark corners of the internet by those who've described the pop star as an "Aryan goddess." (Breitbart, a website that has offered a platform for alt-right views, tweeting out the lyrics to her new single certainly didn't help.)

Swift has yet to respond to the ACLU's letter, as well as HuffPost's request for comment.
TITLE: ACLU Drags Taylor Swift For Trying To Silence Critic

Ce moment dont j'avais tant rÃªvÃ©!!! J'y Ã©tais pour de vrai! Une organisation parfaite. Tout est fait pour t'en mettre plein les yeux, que Ã§a soit du petit goodies (petit gadget) Ã  l'effigie de la course Ã  acheter, jusqu'Ã  la peluche, en passant par tous les styles de vÃªtements techniques ou non! Dingue!

Dimanche 5 novembre: Ã§a y est, c'est le Jour J! RÃ©veil Ã  5h, transport en bus depuis l'hÃ´tel jusqu'au lieu du dÃ©part, je suis dÃ©jÃ  concentrÃ© sur ma course tout en canalisant mon excitation.

Je vous laisse imaginer la sÃ©curitÃ©: US marines, police, hÃ©licos, camions bennes et camions poubelles anti-voiture bÃ©lier barrant toutes les rues donnant sur le parcours, portiques Ã  mÃ©taux filtrant les spectateurs et les coureurs avec fouilles individuelles par les policiers. Ã‰videmment, j'avais encore Ã  l'esprit l'attentat qui avait eu lieu le 31 octobre au sud de Manhattan alors que j'Ã©tais Ã  quelques blocs de lÃ  quand Ã§a s'est passÃ© et qui avait fait 8 morts et de nombreux blessÃ©s; et celui aussi de Boston plusieurs annÃ©es auparavant durant le marathon. Mais la sÃ©curitÃ© Ã©tait telle qu'on se sentait rÃ©ellement sÃ©curisÃ©s. Notre tour-opÃ©rator nous a confiÃ© que la municipalitÃ© de New York avait envisagÃ© un temps d'annuler le marathon, mais nous n'avions pas Ã©tÃ© informÃ©s de cela directement. Je pense que tout le monde avait malgrÃ© tout en tÃªte un gros risque d'attentat.

Une organisation parfaite. Tout est fait pour t'en mettre plein les yeux. La ville vit et vibre pour cet Ã©vÃ©nement!

9h. C'est le dÃ©part. Mais avant, l'hymne national amÃ©ricain! Instant solennel et Ã©mouvant je l'avoue, mÃªme si je ne suis pas amÃ©ricain. Tout Ã©vÃ©nement sportif commence ainsi en AmÃ©rique. Il faut reconnaÃ®tre que Ã§a prend vraiment aux tripes juste avant de s'Ã©lancer.

Enfin le coup de canon est tirÃ© pour donner le top dÃ©part, avec un survol d'hÃ©lico au-dessus de nous!

Je vous laisse imaginer la sÃ©curitÃ©: US marines, police, hÃ©licos, camions bennes et camions poubelles anti-voiture bÃ©lier.

Les fous du bitumes sont lancÃ©s. La musique "New York, New York" chantÃ©e par Frank Sinatra ouvre la danse de ces dizaines de milliers de jambes qui se mettent en action. Il y aura d'ailleurs des orchestres tout le long du parcours pour en faire une vraie fÃªte. GÃ©niale ambiance! Une foule continue de spectateurs le long du trajet supporte les coureurs par ses encouragements. On crie, on agite des cloches, on hurle, on chante. Il y a mÃªme des gens qui nous proposent des bananes coupÃ©es, des quartiers d'orange et tas d'autres choses Ã  manger. Je me suis mÃªme demandÃ© s'il n'y avait pas des cheesecakes! Bref, tout le monde est avec nous et nous soutient avec un enthousiasme dÃ©lirant! Ã‡a nous fait supporter les moments tellement difficiles.

Il y aura des orchestres tout le long du parcours pour en faire une vraie fÃªte. GÃ©niale ambiance!

Je portais un T-shirt Ã  l'effigie de mon pays et j'ai donc souvent entendu "Allez la France!" avec un accent amÃ©ricain. Ã‡a m'a fait sourire. Mais Ã§a m'a portÃ©. Et les enfants comme les adultes te tendent la main pour que tu la leur tapes sur ton passage!! Ce climat joyeux et fraternel me fait oublier la bruine un peu gÃªnante et me permet de relancer mon allure tout en me donnant des frissons dans les jambes.

Je suis arrivÃ© au bout de 3h30. Je n'avais plus de jus, tant ce marathon-lÃ  est difficile en raison de ses lignes droites infinies qui montent; on m'avait prÃ©venu mais la joie et l'Ã©motion d'Ãªtre finisher m'ont permis d'oublier, encore 24 heures aprÃ¨s, mes crampes et mes courbatures; mais j'ai Ã©tÃ© fier de porter ma mÃ©daille autour du cou, comme la tradition le veut Ã  New York, jusqu'au retour en France. On m'a souvent arrÃªtÃ© pour me fÃ©liciter et me dire "YES ,YOU DID IT!"

YES ,YOU DID IT!

Je signe donc, avec encore plus de motivation, pour celui de Londres l'annÃ©e prochaine mÃªme si cela a exigÃ© de ma part beaucoup d'entraÃ®nement et de sacrifices pour m'y prÃ©parer. Mais voilÃ , la passion de courir surpasse tout! Cependant, je sais que celui de NYC restera gravÃ© dans ma mÃ©moire comme le plus gÃ©nial, le plus incroyable, le plus fou!

CULTURE

iPhone X Ã¨ davvero "il piÃ¹ resistente di sempre"? Non provate a rifare questi test di caduta

Apple ha definito i nuovi iPhone 8 e iPhone X "gli smartphone con il vetro piÃ¹ resistente di sempre". La spesa puÃ² arrivare fino a 1359 euro e naturalmente ci si augura in effetti che il Gorilla Glass 5 che li avvolge non vada in frantumi dopo una caduta accidentale. Per questo i cosiddetti "drop test" vanno alla grande sul web: gli YouTuber piÃ¹ coraggiosi, e con grande seguito, sacrificano uno dei nuovi esemplari riprendendo la sua caduta da almeno due altezze: 1 metro, corrispondente piÃ¹ o meno a una fuoriuscita dalla tasca dei pantaloni, e 1,5 metri, l'altezza a cui si tiene normalmente il dispositivo quando si usa per telefonare. Quello che state vedendo Ã¨ uno dei test piÃ¹ cliccati su YouTube dalla data di uscita dell'iPhone X, lo scorso 3 novembre. L'autore del video mette a confronto la caduta dell'iPhone piÃ¹ costoso sul mercato con quella dell'iPhone 8. I risultati ottenuti in questo test, ovviamente, non sanciscono ufficialmente nÃ© definitivamente la resistenza del nuovo smartphone. Altre prove, sul web, hanno registrato esiti diversi

SUMMARY:
Law enforcement officials also reported that witnesses at the scene claimed Saipov yelled out the phrase â€œAllahu akbarâ€ during the attack.
CNN: We know that Allahu Akbar is a popular phrase among terrorists.
A Phrase With A Profound Spiritual HistoryThe phrase Allahu akbar has a long history of use within Islam.
The phrase Allahu akbar is also used by non-Muslim Arab speakers, since â€œAllahâ€ is the Arabic word for God.
This summer, an Italian mayor threatened that anyone who shouts Allahu akbar in a main square in Venice would be immediately shot.
TEXT:
â€œAllahu akbarâ€ is an Arabic phrase that translates to â€œGod is greater.â€ In the wake of a deadly attack in New York on Tuesday, this inherently spiritual phrase is being used in a different context: to signify a link to political terrorism.

Eight people were killed and 12 others injured after a driver plowed through pedestrians and cyclists in lower Manhattan on Tuesday. The suspect, a 29-year-old Uzbek immigrant identified as Sayfullo Habibullaevic Saipov, rammed into a school bus and exited the truck holding imitation firearms before being shot by police.

On Wednesday, federal prosecutors accused Saipov of plotting out a terror attack inspired by propaganda from the so-called Islamic State. Law enforcement officials also reported that witnesses at the scene claimed Saipov yelled out the phrase â€œAllahu akbarâ€ during the attack.

JEWEL SAMAD via Getty Images Investigators work around the wreckage of a Home Depot pickup truck a day after it was used in a terror attack in New York on November 1, 2017.

This phrase has also reportedly been invoked during other terror attacks this year â€• in Belgium, the United Kingdom, France, and Spain. As a result of the way it surfaces during these acts of violence, Allahu akbar has become something that provokes fear among those who are unfamiliar with or suspicious of Islam.

CNN: We know that Allahu Akbar is a popular phrase among terrorists.



COME ON MUSLIMS SAY THIS EVERYDAY IN PRAYER. â€” Rowaida Abdelaziz (@Rowaida_Abdel) October 31, 2017

To hear a spiritual phrase that Muslims use in their everyday lives twisted in this violent way is incredibly frustrating, said Rabiah Ahmed, director of media and public affairs at the Muslim Public Affairs Council.

â€³[Allahu Akbar] has been used in traditional Muslim prayers for centuries and is used as a peaceful reminder of their religious commitment. They are also the opening words of the Adhan (Islamic call to prayer) and is also often used in approval in the same way Christians say Amen,â€™â€ Ahmed told HuffPost.

â€œIts extremely painful and frustrating [to see it misused], and unfortunately, just another example of how our religion is co-opted by those those who act outside of it.â€

John Moore via Getty Images A makeshift memorial stands on a bike path in lower Manhattan on November 1, 2017 in New York City. Eight people were killed and 12 injured on October 31 when suspect 29-year-old Sayfullo Saipov intentionally drove a truck onto the path.

A Phrase With A Profound Spiritual History

The phrase Allahu akbar has a long history of use within Islam. It expresses a sentiment that is at its heart a theological reflection about humanityâ€™s place in the world: That no matter what trials or victories people face, God is greater than it all.

It appears a few times in the Quran, but only mid-sentence, according to Imam Omar Suleiman, president of the Yaqeen Institute for Islamic Research. The phrase is more explicit in the sunnah, a set of teachings about the way of life modeled by Islamâ€™s founder, the Prophet Muhammad.

Suleiman pointed in particular to a hadith â€• one of the collected reports about the prophet â€• where Muhammad is recorded as saying, â€œAllah is Greater, Mightier than all His creation. He is Mightier than what I fear and dread.â€

â€œWhat it suggests is that God is greater than all our concerns, God is greater than all that is ascribed to him, greater than all the disappointments we have,â€ Suleiman said. â€œGod is greater than our pain, God is greater than our material possessions.â€

Allahu akbar is an affirmation of a belief in a monotheistic God, Suleiman said â€• since it suggests that God has no partners. Belief in absolute monotheism is a core part of orthodox Islamic theology.

The phrase Allahu akbar is also used by non-Muslim Arab speakers, since â€œAllahâ€ is the Arabic word for God. Some Christians from Syria, Lebanon, and other regions in the Levant, say Allahu akbar to express surprise, excitement, puzzlement or dismay â€• in the same way that English speakers may use the phrase â€œOh my God.â€ (Itâ€™s not a religious pronouncement for these Christians, however, and some Arab Christians, such as Egyptâ€™s Copts, do not use it.)

From a theological point of view, the idea that God is greater than human circumstances is not limited to Islam. In English, one verse of the Bible declares, â€œHe who is in you is greater than he who is in the world.â€

A popular Christian worship song by the band MercyMe is based on the verse. Another wildly popular Christian song, by the musician Chris Tomlin, states, â€œOur God is greater, our God is stronger, God you are higher than any other.â€

Nick Jonas has a symbol representing the words â€œGod is greater than the highs and lowsâ€ tattooed on his arm.

A post shared by Nick Jonas (@nickjonas) on Aug 8, 2013 at 5:03pm PDT

Saying Allahu Akbar In Prayer, Joy And Sadness

For Muslims, the phrase Allahu akbar is built into the prayers that are one of the pillars of Islam. It begins the call to prayer, or â€œadhan.â€ Itâ€™s also used as a verbal transition between the different positions Muslims assume during prayer â€• standing up, bowing, kneeling, prostrating on the ground.

â€œThereâ€™s something extremely powerful about saying Allahu akbar and then prostrating yourself, putting your face on the ground in supplication to our creator,â€ Suleiman said. â€œIn Islam, the greatest position of prayer is prostration â€• the more you lower yourself to God, the higher he elevates you.â€

Muslim Girl via Getty Images Muslims repeat Allahu akbar as a transition between different positions used during prayer.

Outside of the context of formal prayer, Allahu akbar is also used by Muslims in moments of celebration, such as when someone passes a hard exam or is accepted into college. It is also said in times of sorrow â€• such as when a dearly loved one passes away.

The phrase is often the first sound Muslims whisper into a babyâ€™s ears at birth and one of the last sounds they hear during a burial, as a body is lowered into the grave.

Suleiman said that often during Islamic fundraisers, every time someone raises their hand to donate the whole audience will say Allahu akbar in celebration of the act of charity.

The phrase is so much a part of daily life that Qasim Rashid, a spokesperson for the Ahmadiyya Muslim community in America, estimates that heâ€™s said it more than 1.6 million times over the course of his life â€• just because of the five daily prayers.

â€œ[Praying] five times a day, since I was about seven years old, it comes out to about 1.6 million times over the last 28 years or so,â€ Rashid told HuffPost. â€œThat doesnâ€™t include when I said Allahu akbar when my kids were born, or when I helped build a hospital, or Michael Jordan made the game winning shot in the NBA finals.â€

â€œItâ€™s part of our celebratory mode, and to believe that it could mean something violent is asinine,â€ he said.

For the record, "Allahu Akbar" has no inherent political/violent connotation meriting instant terror diagnosis.I say it like 20 times a day. â€” rabia chaudry (@rabiasquared) October 31, 2017

The Consequences Of Misusing The Phrase

Despite the prevalence of this religious concept, Hind Makki, an interfaith educator and activist, told HuffPost said she feels that a stigma has become attached to the phrase in American culture â€• particularly when it is said in Arabic.

â€œItâ€™s one of those Arabic phrases that people who arenâ€™t Muslim or arenâ€™t really familiar with Islam treat with dread because they connect it to a crime,â€ she said.

â€œItâ€™s frustrating because we have seen how many mass shootings and mass murders there have been recently and several of the suspects, I would assume have some kind of ideological bent,â€ she said, referring in particular to the Las Vegas shooter Stephen Paddock, whose rampage in October left 58 people dead and hundreds more injured. â€œBut because the person is not from a Muslim background, or didnâ€™t yell Allahu akbar, people are like, â€˜We donâ€™t know why he did it.â€™â€

Some Muslims have become wary of saying the phrase, or speaking in Arabic in general, while in public. The feeling of anxiety is felt heavily on planes, where some have reported being taken off flights for speaking in Arabic.

Rashid said that as a result of how the phrase is treated in America, he tries to use it as much as possible around his children.

â€œI donâ€™t want them to feel intimidated. I feel young Muslims feel intimidated using words like jihad, or Allahu akbar, or even saying â€˜assalamu alaikumâ€™ [a common greeting] in public,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s an unfortunate side effect of whatâ€™s happening right now.â€

Burhaan Kinu via Getty Images Allahu akbar is said during prayer and also in everyday conversations -- as an expression of celebration.

Another side effect of misusing and misunderstanding Islamic phrases is that it leads to fears of a backlash against the Muslim community. Anti-Muslim hate crimes have increased dramatically since the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks.

Allahu akbar has been weaponized in the past by people whose intent is to harm Muslims. In Quebec City, Canada in January, it was reportedly yelled out by a suspect with far-right, white nationalist views during a deadly attack on a mosque community.

This summer, an Italian mayor threatened that anyone who shouts Allahu akbar in a main square in Venice would be immediately shot.

Ahmed, of MPAC, said she believes every terrorist act done in the name of Islam not only takes away innocent lives but also threatens the security of Americans who are Muslim.

â€œBecause there is so much misinformation and misunderstanding about our faith and community, those who seek revenge for these attacks will usually direct their anger toward the first innocent Muslim they see on the streets, at school, and at public places,â€ she told HuffPost. â€œSince 9/11, this has been our reality. Whenever there is any terror incident done in our name, we mourn not only as Americans, but we mourn the hijacking of our faith and brace ourselves for potential backlash.â€

Thatâ€™s why Ahmed believes education about Islam is crucial. Instead of allowing the Islamic State to define what Allahu akbar means, she said itâ€™s important to seek authentic, legitimate voices and interpretations of the phrase.
TITLE: Here's What You Need To Know About The Phrase 'Allahu Akbar'

It's safe to say those times are well and truly behind us because 'glitter coffee' is what the trendy kids drink these days.
'Coffee By Di Bella' is the Aussie company behind these glorious and glittery beverages.
They're made just like any other coffee, with the beans, the coffee shot and the milk.
They've been using gold glitter to jazz-up everything from their cappuccinos to their turmeric lattes.
They're even offering free pony rides with every purchase of a glitter coffee.
TEXT:
Remember the simpler days when sugar was the only thing people ever put in their coffees? It's safe to say those times are well and truly behind us because 'glitter coffee' is what the trendy kids drink these days.

'Coffee By Di Bella' is the Aussie company behind these glorious and glittery beverages. They're made just like any other coffee, with the beans, the coffee shot and the milk. Of course, the not-so-secret ingredient is a generous helping of edible glitter.

A post shared by vinita (@miss_vinita_) on Nov 5, 2017 at 6:57am PST

A post shared by Bernadette Rigney (@bernadette_fab) on Nov 4, 2017 at 11:48pm PDT

A post shared by Ivy Wild London (@ivywildlondon) on Nov 6, 2017 at 11:41am PST

An England based coffee shop called 'Melbourne in Lichfield' is another cafe that has been experimenting with these glitter-topped drinks. They've been using gold glitter to jazz-up everything from their cappuccinos to their turmeric lattes. They're even offering free pony rides with every purchase of a glitter coffee.

A post shared by Deb Pease (@melbourneinlichfield) on Nov 1, 2017 at 3:54am PDT

A post shared by Deb Pease (@melbourneinlichfield) on Nov 1, 2017 at 2:05am PDT

A post shared by Deb Pease (@melbourneinlichfield) on Nov 6, 2017 at 11:01am PST

So if you're having a rough day or your plain, coffee-coloured morning beverage isn't dazzling how you'd like, glitter coffee could be the thing you've been waiting for.
TITLE: Glitter Coffee: The Love Child Of A Latte And A Disco Ball

SUMMARY:
I grew up saying â€œAllahu Akbarâ€ numerous times every day.
Allahu AkbarThe saying literally means God is the greatest.
It is required of all Muslims to say several times during prayer, which is demanded five times a day.
So when and why is the phrase Allahu Akbar used as a battle cry, when a terrorist is about to kill someone?
Hereâ€™s where the double standard hurts: When that man killed 58 people in Las Vegas, the word terrorist was not uttered by anyone.
TEXT:
I grew up saying â€œAllahu Akbarâ€ numerous times every day.

And no, I wasnâ€™t, and am not, a terrorist.

I wasnâ€™t someone who blew buildings up, killed people or shot a missile from my rocket launcher. As far as the West is concerned, those are the events associated with the saying when something bad is about to happen. People of the West are terrified of the phrase.

I was a Muslim boy trying to pray as many times as he could amidst a life of love and peace, in a home that did not condone any terrorism. My father was a poet who read me love poetry instead of nursery rhymes. He uttered the phrase when he prayed. If love existed in the form of a man, it was my father.

â€œLove everyone,â€ was the phrase he uttered almost daily. To him, there was not a problem he couldnâ€™t solve with love.

Allahu Akbar

The saying literally means God is the greatest. It is required of all Muslims to say several times during prayer, which is demanded five times a day. On the average a Muslim ends up saying it hundreds of times. The words are also used as a celebration of life: When a baby is born, when a couple marry or when a veteran returns home safe.

The word Islam means surrender. Youâ€™re supposed to surrender to God and worship him. Love, mercy and compassion are uttered several hundred times a day by any Muslim when they say Besm Allah Alrahman Alraheem, In The Name Of God The Merciful The Compassionate. That saying is uttered before you do anything.

So when and why is the phrase Allahu Akbar used as a battle cry, when a terrorist is about to kill someone? The latest incident was the horrific act in New York when the terrorist shouted the phrase before the police shot him, and after he killed eight people and injured many more.

For the majority of Muslims, to shout Godâ€™s name as you killed the innocent is an abomination. Muslims no more want innocent people killed than anyone else. So why is the phrase used by terrorists?

For the same reason ISIS and Al-Qaida exist: The misinterpretation of Islam. When you use religion as the motive for you actions, you have the power to appeal to the masses. Itâ€™s a brain washing if you will. The terrorists who flew the planes into the World Trade Center on September 11th are no different than any suicide bomber in Israel/Palestine, are no different that the one who mowed down bicyclists in New York. They are people who misunderstood and misused the religion. They are sick and twisted and evil.

The phrase is to remind Muslims that God is supreme. Thatâ€™s it. It was never to be used as a battle cry during horrendous actions furthering political agendas with evil motives.

My heart sank when I heard the terrorist shouted the saying after the attack. I will never understand the link between Islam and Terrorism. The Islam I grew up amidst condemns such actions. It preaches love and peace and tranquility and feeding the hungry and clothing the poor and sheltering the homeless. One of the five main requirements of Islam in addition to prayer and fasting is to give a percentage of your money to the poor.

Is There A Difference?

To me, there is no difference between the terrorists who shout Allahu Akbar when committing a crime and those white nationalists and racists who shouted â€œJews will not replace usâ€ in Charlottesville â€• Virginia recently.

Hereâ€™s where the double standard hurts: When that man killed 58 people in Las Vegas, the word terrorist was not uttered by anyone. Why is it only attached to people who claim Islamic affiliation?

The Quran was brought down to Muhammad in the seventh century. The verses which preach war and fighting were contextual and apply to the time when he and his followers had no choice but to fight back, or die. It is no different than the Old Testament which contains many verses preaching war and killing.

In Deuteronomy Chapter 2, Verses 32-37, Moses is told to kill men, women, and children:

â€œAnd the LORD said unto me, Behold, I have begun to give Siphon and his land before thee: begin to possess, that thou mayest inherit his land. Then Sihon came out against us, he and all his people, to fight at Jahaz. And the LORD our God delivered him before us; and we smote him, and his sons, and all his people. And we took all his cities at that time, and utterly destroyed the men, and the women, and the little ones , of every city, we left none to remain. From Aroer, which is by the brink of the river of Arnon, and from the city that is by the river, even unto Gilead, there was not one city too strong for us: the LORD our God delivered all unto us.â€

How is this any different than whatâ€™s in the Quran? And why are Muslims judged by a different prism? Most of the Quran preaches love and harmony and helping those who have not. Take this for example:

â€œAnd feed with food the needy wretch, the orphan and the prisoner, for love of Him (saying): We feed you, for the sake of Allah only. We wish for no reward nor thanks from you.â€ [76:8-9]

Any ancient religious book can be misunderstood and misrepresented. The Ku Klux Klan said the Jesus was the first Klansman. They burned crosses to spread their ill will. How is that any different?

My Sister

Karim Shamsi-Basha My sisters Mimi, right, and Rowaida.

My sister Rowaida lives in New York. We chatted last night when I wanted to make sure her head covering was not causing any problems. In the past when terrorists committed atrocities in the name of Islam, women with head coverings were profiled. She said everything was fine, and prayed for those people affected by the terror.

My sister prayed for them.

She is a teacher and her husband is an architect. All they want is food, water, and a roof over their heads, and for their children to thrive. They have four: a computer scientist, a doctor, a physical therapist, and a pharmacist. They love like anyone else, and they have compassion and mercy and empathy like anyone else.

The covering on her head says two things: Modesty and humility.

A Wish Or Two

I have one wish, well maybe two.

The first is for my children to thrive and go through life without any judgment based on their last name.

The second is for this world to know that Muslims mean no one any harm. The people who mean harm are as far from Islam as the KKK is far from Christianity.

My religion is love.
TITLE: I Say Allahu Akbar. I Am Not A Terrorist.

And on Saturday, the local hockey community rallied to support Marissa, her parents Jan and Jim, and her younger sisters Madelyn, 12, and Charlotte, 9, who also play minor hockey.
The Kennebecasis Valley Minor Hockey Association, which includes the towns of Rothesay and Quispamsis, is the largest minor hockey association in New Brunswick, Fletcher said.
"The Gootjes family is beyond appreciative of the support and love that is pouring in for Marissa," Patrick wrote.
TEXT:
Marissa Gootjes was typical Grade 9 student, until she wasn't.

The 14-year-old girl, who is also a minor hockey player and a girl guide, was diagnosed with brain cancer after suffering a seizure Thanksgiving weekend. Her tumour has since been removed, but she has to undergo a year of treatment at the IWK Health Centre in Halifax, N.S., a four-hour drive from her home in Quispamsis, N.B.

"Within two weeks, she went from being a typical Grade 9 student, to having a brain tumour discovered and removed (and was out of ICU within a day, like the champ she is!)," family friend Krista Patrick wrote on the GoFundMe page she started to support the Gootjes family.

@girlguidesofcan friends tweet your support to Pathfinder #MarissaTheFierce as she battles brain cancer pic.twitter.com/ne51Kt5y2W â€” NB PEI Girl Guides (@NBPEIGirlGuides) November 3, 2017

In just 12 days the page, called "Marissa The Fierce," has raised nearly $25,000 to help the family face the cost of extended absences, travel, testing, and upgrades to the family home (Marissa's immune system will be "severely compromised," according to the GoFundMe page).

And on Saturday, the local hockey community rallied to support Marissa, her parents Jan and Jim, and her younger sisters Madelyn, 12, and Charlotte, 9, who also play minor hockey.

With a six-team benefit game, the community raised more than $19,000 for the family, Lynn Fletcher, the director of communications for the Kennebecasis Valley Minor Hockey Association told HuffPost Canada.

"The energy in the rink was electric," Fletcher said, estimating that about 1,000 people came to the fundraiser.

"With three girls in hockey, everyone knows one of the Gootjes girls."

The Kennebecasis Valley Minor Hockey Association, which includes the towns of Rothesay and Quispamsis, is the largest minor hockey association in New Brunswick, Fletcher said.

"Hockey is pretty big here," she added.

Marissa wasn't well enough to play Saturday, but she sat on the bench with her team during the final game, Fletcher said. Her teammates bring her jersey with them to every game they play, Fletcher added.

"So even when she's not there, she's there," Fletcher said.

And on Saturday, Marissa's sisters were able to lead their own teams onto the ice to help support their family.

It's not just the local hockey community that's rallied for "Marissa The Fierce."

Canadian ice hockey player Caroline Ouellette, a four-time Olympic gold medalist, donated a signed Team Canada jersey to Marissa and her sisters this weekend, Fletcher added. And on Sunday, former ice hockey player, Canadian Hayley Wickenheiser (who also boasts four Olympic gold medals), called Marissa to say she was thinking about her, Fletcher said.

Marissa started her treatment Nov. 6, according to an update on her GoFundMe page.

"The Gootjes family is beyond appreciative of the support and love that is pouring in for Marissa," Patrick wrote.

"Let's help this family be able to focus 100% on fighting this thing."

Also on HuffPost:
TITLE: New Brunswick's Hockey Community Is Rallying To Support A Girl With Brain Cancer

SUMMARY:
CANBERRA -- One Nation leader Pauline Hanson has launched her Queensland election campaign on Monday with a champagne start to her party's "Battler Bus" tour of the state's regions.
She is launching a 'battler bus' with champagne.
The Battler Bus also includes a hashtag for people to follow on social media, #PeopleB4Politics.
'The3million' campaign wants EU nationals to maintain their current rights under a withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union.
#PeopleB4Politics https://t.co/yWH665av9j â€” the3million (@The3Million) November 4, 2017#EUcitizens are your neighbours, colleagues, family members, friends.
TEXT:
Pauline Hanson: "I think it's time for One Nation and honestly I think this is going to be bigger than what it was in 1998."

CANBERRA -- One Nation leader Pauline Hanson has launched her Queensland election campaign on Monday with a champagne start to her party's "Battler Bus" tour of the state's regions.

While a smash of bubbly is a common choice for christening a vessel, the use of champagne fizz in this instance has caught the eye of a few political opponents as being not exactly "battlerish".

She is launching a 'battler bus' with champagne. YOU CAN'T MAKE THIS UP. pic.twitter.com/gO2gSOFZKj â€” Sam Dastyari (@samdastyari) November 6, 2017

The launch of the white and blue bus bearing Hanson's face constitutes a late joining of the Queensland election trail for the senator as she was caught out of the country on a parliamentary trip to India when the Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk called the election.

Hanson confirmed a preference deal with the Katter's Australian Party ahead of Labor and the LNP but would not confirm whether the two parties would vote together as a block in the next state parliament.

"I think it's time for One Nation and honestly I think this is going to be bigger than what it was in 1998," she told reporters in Brisbane before the bus took off.

The Battler Bus also includes a hashtag for people to follow on social media, #PeopleB4Politics.

A quick search of the hashtag did not find a flood of One Nation mentions; rather it has been used in United Kingdom in a campaign to protect the rights of millions of European citizens who live in the UK but will be affected by Brexit.

'The3million' campaign wants EU nationals to maintain their current rights under a withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union.

In particular they want EU nationals to keep the right to bring family members to the UK, including from outside the EU, as now.

The residency #citizensrights of 4.5 million people need to be sorted before talks can move on to the future relationship. #PeopleB4Politics https://t.co/yWH665av9j â€” the3million (@The3Million) November 4, 2017

#EUcitizens are your neighbours, colleagues, family members, friends. Please support us to put #PeopleB4Politics . #citizensrights â€” Anke in Brexitland (@solsikke66) November 4, 2017

No-one owns hashtags and the One Nation "Battler Bus" juggernaut may soon soon take over its use but the anti-immigration populist party is starting the week with a few contradictions.
TITLE: Pauline Hanson Adopts Pro-Immigration Hashtag #peopleb4politics For Queensland Election
